sp.l: In theſe dread times, when WAR's unſated rage
Crowds with diſaſters LIFE's eventful ſtage,
When the full trumpet and embattled ire
Drown the ſoft warblings of the ſlighted Lyre,
The MUSES' lonely haunts no more diſplay,
Among their with'ring blooms, the POET's BAY
The partial ſoil, THE LAUREL only rears,
For martial wreaths, that vegetate in tears.
At ſuch a time, ſuperfluous ſeems the art,
To melt with fabled woes the ſadden'd heart;
The ſorrowing MUSES need themſelves relief,
And FANCY droops in ſympathetic grief.
The TRAGIC MAID, indeed, may ſooth her care,
And future ſcenes from paſſing ills prepare;
But for the LAUGHING NYMPH, alas! can ſhe
At eaſe preſume with her untimely glee!
Is there a place, amidſt the world's alarms,
In ſafety ſtill to heed her frolic charms?
Yes—in the ſhades of BRITAIN's happy Iſle,
Still may the COMIC MUSE ſecurely ſmile;
Still with her tuneful Siſters ſhelter here,
Nor ſavage ANARCHY's vain menace fear!
Here no DIRE RUFFIANS, dead to gen'rous joy,
All that endears and brightens life deſtroy;
Or, drench'd in blood, with impious rage combine,
Trampling o'er THRONES, to cruſh the HALLOW'D SHRINE!
No DESPOT here exacts a ſlaviſh awe,
The caſual impulſe of his paſſions LAW.
Here on a rock, ſecure amid the ſtorm,
Dwells LIBERTY, in fair monarchic form.
Around her FAME, with venerable grace,
THREE MATCHLESS COLUMNS, fortify the place.
Enthron'd within, pre-eminently great,
Sits awful JUSTICE, in majeſtic ſlate,
Of LQUAL LAWS the animating ſoul,
And ſtation'd HIGHEST, to ſurvey THE WHOLE;
Her SWORD by MERCY check'd, as urg'd by MIGHT,
Her CROWN the SANCTION of a PEOPLE'S RIGHT.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
div.p: SCENE, a Village about fifteen Miles from London.

div.head: THE WORLD IN A VILLAGE.
ACT I.
SCENE I. A neat Parlour. Margery diſcovered adjuſting it and ſinging.
div.p: AH, dame! ſo that Miſs Louiſa's room is dizen'd out, all the reſt of the houſe may go at ſixes and ſevens!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Huſband! How cruſty you've got with our lodger Miſs Louiſa, only becauſe ſhe's a lady, and you think ſhe has a deal of money.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why to be ſure her money did not do much miſchief when it bought tidy warm cloathing for half the poor of our village, and the ſetting up the little ſchool and paying you for teaching the children, as our raſcally rich folks here refuſed to eſtabliſh one; our gentry expect forſooth, 'cauſe I'm a miller, think I muſt cringe and ſneak; but I'll never bow to the golden calf! People to get money ſtick at no villany or meanneſs, and then they're as ſaucy—Dame, I've been round the cuſtomers to gather in rent for my landlord Maſter Allbut. Here. (Takes out a bank-note.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ten pounds! I ſuppoſe its having ſo much money that's made you ſo ſaucy this morning.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
Ecod, wife, I believe ſo. As I come up ſtreet cou'dn't tell what was the matter with me; met honeſt Dick the cobler—came out with his "good morrow, Maſter Jollyboy." I felt a ſort of a—thought he might as well have ſaid nothing. Tom the farrier gave me a friendly ſmack o' th' ſhoulder; I had a mind to knock him down
for his joke: then, now, coming into my own houſe, forgot to ſtoop, and bump'd my forehead againſt the top o' the door-caſe. Oh, ho! then it's the caſh has done all this! I wiſh 'twas gone, for while I have it I feel I ſhall be as impudent as the devil.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Madam Louiſa, (looking out.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Doctor Grigthy with her! Tho' he's now our apothecary, and ſets up alſo to be a wine-merchant, the lady wou'dn't be ſo proud of his company, did ſhe know he was once our barber.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Be quiet, huſband. Doctor Grigſby is a fine man!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: What, becauſe when you were ſick his bottles came in packets, till I taſted, and found all the while the doctor had been ſupplying you with cherry-brandy.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Well, my kind good friend, (looking about.) Why how very handſome you've made my room look! how much I'm obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Dr. Grigſby! I wou'dn't let him cure my cat of a tooth-ach. The fellow has made money out of people's folly, and now don't know how to behave himſelf.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I wiſh you'd learn how to behave yourſelf; ſtrutting about with your hat on, and a lady in the room.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I know nothing about ladies or gentlemen. That fellow was a good barber till money ſpoiled him—my hat! (takes it off), my hat's here—and now it's there, (puts it on.) What ſignifies where a man's hat is? Hats and beads— ladies—gentlemen—good as another—hem!(ſiruts off muttering.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Plague take you for a fool!—as good-natur'd a man as ever broke bread, but when he gets theſe fancies in his noddle.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Where there is real worth theſe little oddities of humour rather excite pleaſantry than reſentment.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Od, I'll give it him!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Never mind now, my kind Margery—I'm ſorry I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Leave us! Well, if I didn't expect my ſilly huſband's behaviour wou'd bring it to this.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
Huſh! your huſband has nothing to do in it:— I'm certain I can confide in you;—you know little of me;— I'm a ſtranger;—but I'll not trouble you with more of my affairs than juſt neceſſary. You doubtleſs concluded from
the triſling ſums I expended on my firſt coming here into your village, that I muſt of courſe be ſome very rich body or other.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: La, Ma'am, I didn't expect you for that!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I believe it. From certain family circumſtances, immaterial to any but myſelf, I have been obliged to—however, you know I came from Ireland—have been in France, and—I am unfortunately not on the beſt terms with my friends, till a make up can be brought about to my wiſh. Not being over ſtrong in purſe, I plann'd a frugal retirement; the variety of calls upon the feelings of my heart have at length exhauſted my little finance; therefore— but mind, I'm not caſt down—no, I'm as happy—

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Dear, I'm ſo ſorry—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, if you go to pity me I ſhall be very much affronted.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I affront you!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Lord! I never was more gay or cheerful in my whole life: but I'll tell you—You know, you and your huſband are very honeſt people, and get nothing but what you hardly earn; now, why ſhould I from my extravagance become a burden to you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Extravagance! 'twas your charity—burden! your ſtay will be a bleſſing to us—pay us when you can, or never, (weeping.) Oh, my ſweet lady!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, perhaps I mayn't leave your village. But yet, better ſome ſtrange place—tho' who here knows me— (aſide.) Margery, I've conceiv'd a thought to ſtay among you without inconvenience to any one; I think I cou'd be uſeful to your Miſtreſs Allbut, here. From her character of a paſſion for literary amuſements, ſhe might, perhaps, afford me a ſituation to read, or tranſlate French; tranſcribe her poetry, for I am told ſhe has wrote a number of pretty things; or cou'd, upon occaſion, dreſs up a cap for her—eh, Margery, cou'd you recommend me? You know you told me ſhe ſometimes reads her poems to you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Eh—Well, I'll call on her, my lady.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, none of your lady's to me—I muſt ſoon unlady myſelf. Upon my honour I ſhall be exceeding angry if you are not even merry. There now, that's a dear good woman, (ſhakes hands cordially, and goes to a cheſt of drawers.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Wife, if 'Squire Allbut's corn comes, tell 'em it muſt wait; for I've got firſt a buſhel to grind for old Budget the tinker.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Don't talk to me.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Eh!—What have you found a pot of gold under an old wall?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah, huſband! this dear young lady our lodger—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ay, well.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Her diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Well, if ſhe's diſtreſs'd about any one's poverty, her hand knows the way to her pocket, a road it has ſo often gone upon like occaſions.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ay, but I may as well put my hand into my pocket.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Deuce o' your riddles—What's the matter with with you and ſhe?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I tell you at laſt, ſhe herſelf is really diſtreſs'd, and won't ſtay becauſe ſhe can't pay us.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Diſtreſs'd! Oh, dear!—one that was ſo ready to relieve every body elſe, now to want it herſelf. (Louiſa advances, Jollyboy takes off his hat with great reſpect,) Madam, I'm ſure I'm vaſtly concerned that any paſt conduct of mine ſhou'd have given you the leaſt uneaſineſs. You've done us too much honour in coming under our roof; and if any improper freedoms of ours have given you offence, you have only to blame your own condeſcenſion. Madam, we are but ignorant people, and if we have fail'd in our reſpect, I humbly crave your pardon.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Then Margery has told him. This is an attempt at irony—Become the ſubject of ridicule! I thought I could endure poverty, but I was wrong— (aſide.) Sir, it's not immediately in my power to diſcharge what I already owe you, but hope ſoon; for I can aſſure you it wou'd give me infinite pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Wou'd it? then—tho' I go to jail for my own rent— (aſide.) True, I forgot—Ma'am, this was left for you juſt now; 'twas inclos'd in a paper—thought at firſt 'twas for myſelf, ſo broke it open—I beg pardon—tho' there was nothing written in't.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ten pounds! Who left it?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I did aſk, but can't find who.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
Then my circumſtances are known! Is there ſuch benevolence? However, how to appropriate this
doesn't want a conſideration. Pray let me know what I'm indebted to you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Oh, Madam.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I requeſt—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Well, Madam, ſince here now have I given what I had to pay my own rent; 'twill grind my heart to apolgoiſe to Landlord Allbut—but I've ſet her heart at eaſe, and that's good amends.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (without.) No: I want my chay; ſo put that hamper of wine, and take the med'cines round in the little cart.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Madam, now you ſhould look above this Maſter Grigſby—you don't know him—a fellow taken from ſitting with numb'd fingers, wig-weaving, into a doctor's ſervice, to bruſh his coat and frizzle his pate, picking up hard words from the apothecary's boys, marrying the houſekeeper,— throwing her purloinings into a brandy vault and drug-ſhop (ſhe poiſoned herſelf in one of them,) and now, by jargon, ſmiles, lies, and cringes, has glided into the good graces of every family in the village—Oh, he's not dreſſed in his phyſical pomp! When he wants to ſhew his conſequence, pops himſelf into one of the famous fine velvet and gold ſuits left him by his old maſter the phyſician.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: (without.) Indeed, Doctor—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (without.) But I will viſit my patient.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ay, now for Dr. Grigſby's chatt'ring! 'Till he's gone, we may put our tongues in our pockets. Zounds, I wiſh I cou'd ſhut my ears in my tobacco-box.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: (without.) I tell you, Doctor, Miſs Louiſa is not in the humour for jaunting.

div.stage: Enter Grigſby and Margery wrangling, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Teach me humours, defluxions, catarrhs, and cataplaſms!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But, Sir, hadn't you beſt come back to ſhop?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Shop! Get home, you dog, and mix up that ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But, Sir, I forgot what I was to put in it.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A table ſpoonful of any four bottles behind the counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But, Sir, there's Humphrey the wheelwright ſtops for you to bleed him.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Sirrah! My compliments, and I'll wait on his Lordſhip. [Exit Boy.] Hem! Duke Humphrey!—But the ladies muſt always have the preference.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, (curtſeying.) Teazing man! I wiſh he'd go away, (apart to Margery).

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Doctor, the lady wiſhes you'd—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Huſh!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: My dear Madam, never deceive your doctor—but that is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: For me to think of attempting a deception!— Upon my word, Doctor, you have the happieſt mode of compliment—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am, the compliment I put in that mixture was two grains, or, as we of the faculty write in our Latin proſcriptions, dux graniorum, ſix ſcruples, or caterſcrupolibus; and, Madam, I'll venture to aſſirm, that the whole material medicar does not furniſh a cure of more efficacious efficaſey, that is, when we talk of a caſe, razorcaſe—hem! I mean the ſoul-caſe; the body being the caſe of the ſoul, as a bottle is of a bottle of old port; the wine being the ſpirit; and ſo we doctors wax the cork to prevent evaporation or ſomentation; juſt as if a gentleman, to ſhave his chin, would lather his occiput; that is, what we of the faculty call the whole healing art—ſcammony, wild poppy, the ſublimate of ſtyptic water, anthelmintic wine, hicra picra, and the nervous ſyſtem.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, you've certainly a prodigious deal of ſkill; but nature prevents me from opportunities of putting it in practice.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: True, Miſs, I have an immenſe deal of practice— ſo much—the fatigue—knocked up at all hours!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah, Doctor, you're ſuch a fine midwife, 'twou'd comfort one's heart to be your cuſtomer; and ſo I told my huſband t'other night!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I'm capital in the obſtetric art and—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, now pray excuſe me, I'm a little indiſpoſed, and company is—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: If indiſpoſed, Madam, what's better company than your doctor? For in your caſe, as we of the faculty ſay, no aliment ſo mucilaginous as ſheep's head broth: ſome prefer buttermilk, and it is indeed as a lacteal lachrymoligon;—for, Madam, when the diſeaſe proceeds from a viſcid pituitous ſubſtance obſtructing the veſſels of the lungs, we of the faculty call it a ſpurious peripneumony; therefore ripe fruits roaſted, bak'd, or boil'd, ſuch as greengooſe, young parſneps, extract of ſaturn,—then we throw in the bark, and that is, my dear Madam, the—the— nervous ſyſtem.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: But, Doctor, Miſs Louiſa wants a little reſt.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! that's very well—then I know nothing of what a lady wants. I ſee ſhe likes me by her wiſhes to turn me out. (Aſide.)—But, Madam, to promote an emulſive dormitory, or, as Celſus ſays, a nice bit of ſleep or reſt, nothing equal to a ſimple goſs lettice.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Thank ye, Doctor; but I don't need ſoporiſics.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Soap! Dem this barber! how all my patients will be ſlapping ſuds in my teeth—but ſhe muſt be ſome great heireſs here incog. by her having diſperſed ſo much money through the village, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh you a good morning.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Reſt! the nurſe of diſeaſe! You ſee, as a doctor, I ſpeak againſt my own intereſt. Nothing but exerciſe and open air can brace and ſtrengthen the animal functions when the caninus rabies, or dog-madneſs, which we of the faculty call vertigo of the foot, comes—the—the—and that is, Madam, the nervous ſyſtem. Do me the honour of taking an airing in my chaiſe; you may truſt to my whiphand,—ſteady as if touching a vein—I'll drive you—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No: but I'll drive you out of my houſe, if you ſtay to—Don't you ſee that you've already bother'd the lady with your damn'd nonſenſe?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I've what? Oh, this is pretty! What's that you ſaid I did to her?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Poh! Go along.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Go along! Very well, that! Do you know, man, when you talk to a phyſician—Madam, my chaiſe is at the door—permit me the honour of whipping you round the circuitous circle in the grand tour of Eſher, Weſton Green, Moleſey, Hampton Court, Buſhy Park, and Ditton Marſh—the ſight of ſo fine a dreſs'd lady as you ſitting by my ſide—no other barber—hem! wine merchant—phyſician—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Doctor, your politneſs comes particularly acceptable, for I ſhould like a little excurſion, and I aſſure you my purſe now cannot afford the expence of poſt-chaiſes —Well, Margery, you'll ſpeak—Come, Doctor, now for your whip-hand.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Afford! Expence! Any thing broke? (apart to Margery.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah, we are all broke! our hearts are broke!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Eh! All her flaſh end in ſmoke! Oh, ho! (aſide).

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come, Doctor, you ſhall ſet me down at Mr. Allbut's.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Eh! Mem! Your bill did you ſay? We never commit ſuch trifles to book—carry it in my head—"For beſt frontignac—hem! raiſin wine (aſide,) lavender water, low de lucy, and magneſiar holbar"—You are indebted to me the ſum of three pounds three ſhillings and three pence three farthings.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But, Sir, the jaunt.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: It rains, Mem—no head to my chaiſe,—Margery, hav'n't you, as we of the faculty ſay—A miller ſhould always have a parvifol to keep off the rain, (puts on his hat, whiſiles, and walks about cracking his whip.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: (ſtaring). Eh!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (cracking his whip.) All good for the nervous ſyſtem! Mem, I'm making up ſome money, and if you can oblige me by diſcharging that trifle—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Then better remain in my landlord's debt than— This wretch— (aſide)—there, Sir, take your bill out of that — (gives the bank-note to Grigſby.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Yes, Mem: I'll bring you the change in a frizzling of a toopee; but I'll adviſe you, Madam, to exerciſe. Miller, put up a ſwing in your garden between two cherrytrees—ſwing, Mem—nothing but exerciſe and open air can brace and ſtrengthen the animal functions—ſwing! Reſt is the nurſe of diſeaſe—you ſee, as a doctor, I ſpeak againſt my own intereſt. In your caſe, Madam, nothing ſo mucilaginous as ſheep's head broth—then we throw in the bark, and—from ten pounds deduct three pounds three ſhillings and three pence three farthings, and that is what we call the—nervous ſyſtem—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Carried off my bank-note!—Holla, nervous ſyſtem!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Come now with me to Mrs. Allbut's.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ah, I'm ſure you'll not like her. A deuced temper!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p:
I underſtand that Mrs. Allbut is haughty and overbearing—that Mr. Allbut, puffed up with the pride of riches, is the great deſpot of the village—that all their wealth really belongs to a poor widow, Mrs. Bellevue, that lives in the cottage by the warren yonder; but if Mrs. Allbut is ſo proud, I muſt only temporize into humility: Doctor Grigsby's behaviour has convinced me that I ſhou'd uſe every exertion to keep myſelf above pecuniary obligations. A pity it is not ſo! but, when deſtitute of particular defence
and protection, the world ſhou'd be guardians to a lone and helpleſs woman.

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber in Allbut's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: There, the inſtrument's open. (Points to a piano forte.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: But Mr. and Mrs. Allbut may return, and if ſhe finds me at it—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My dear child, if you don't practiſe you'll loſe your muſic; and that will be a pity, Maria, conſidering the proficiency you made in it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Ah, father! my attempt now to retain any elegant accompliſhment is but vanity. What might have been receiv'd with indulgence when we were in eaſy circumſtances, in our preſent humble ſituation at beſt will be overlooked, or, moſt likely, made the object of ridicule.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, indeed, my Love, this reverſe of fortune comes with a double ſeverity, when it ſubjects us to the inſults of this purſe-proud, mean, and illiberal Mr. and Mrs. Allbut. Come, my dear,—there, if your lady ſhou'd hear you, I don't think ſhe can be offended.—Since I am Mr. Allbut's clerk, I muſt to my buſineſs in the coumpting-houſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I have little heart: but, as my father thinks it an object, I will practiſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh, Maſter Jack!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Play on, Molly: I love it, fal, lal, (ſings out of tune.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: If your Mamma ſhou'd come in and hear me?

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Never mind: ſhe'll think it's I. (Maria plays.)

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: (interrupting.) Molly, do you know, I wiſh Mamma wou'dn't be writing her poetries—ſhe troubles the houſe with them. Come, do play to oblige me.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Now, I recollect, I've no reaſon to oblige you, Maſter Jack; how cou'd you go to turn that poor woman and children from the door yeſterday, when I deſired her to wait while I ſtept in to bring her ſomething.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p:
Why 'twas Mamma herſelf. She was reading in the front parlour that poem about humanity, and juſt as her heart and her eyes were melting with the tender pathos of ſorrow, (as ſhe calls it,) the poor hungry brats ſet up ſuch a piping—ſo diſcompoſed Mamma's fine nerves, already unſtrung by pity, that ſhe flew out like an angry turkey, and drove the mother and her infants all out of the court-yard. Do
play. (Maria plays, Maſter Jack interrupting.) Molly! ha! ha! ha! Don't you think Mamma very ſilly, to go and ſet Papa too at making poeſies, and now he begins to trouble the houſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: True, and all his idea of poetry is making a jingle of rhyme, no matter for meaſure, time, place, or reaſon,—but if you will hear me play now, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: My ſervant maid at my inſtrument!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: What a pretty hornpipe!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: You've an excellent ear!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Yes: I've a fine ear for hearing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: And feeling! (pulls him, Maria ſtarts up.)

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Now Mama, what's that for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p:
Oh! enchanting powers of poetry, (reading.)
Sigh to the ſilent ſtreams that ſoftly ſeek the ſeas,
Mar the meek murm'ring melodies that mark the marine breeze. You vile jade!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Molly play on—Mamma, Poll plays better nor you,—ſhe tickles it ſo lightly with her little finger; but you thump it down with your fiſts as if you were breaking biſcuits—then ſhe ſits ſo quiet—ſit Molly—and here, Mamma, you go wagging your head about like an artichoke, (ſits down and mimicks extravagantly.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (curtſeys to Maria.) Oh, do pray, Miſs; oblige us with a canzonet, (ironical.)

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Molly made this ſong herſelf; I know ſhe did.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Writes poetry! Here's a ſaucy ſlut! (aſide)— What my Arioſto! Heavens! if ſhe hasn't been pulling my books out of my ſtudy—Perhaps we've a Sappho in the houſe and don't know it!—I dare ſay you have the aſſurance to be full of tender ſentiment and ſenſibility.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: No, Ma'am;—you can't think I've any feeling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Upon my honor ſhe fancies herſelf a young lady!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Well, Mamma, all the village calls her Miſs Maria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Miſs! ha, ha, ha!—Oh! I ſhall faint—the Maria!—Hadn't you better at once call yourſelf Laura Maria? there's my ſon that will have a tolerable fortune, he's call'd by every body plain Jack.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: By'r leave, Mamma,—even Dr. Grigſby calls me Maſter Jack.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Ma'am, it's a matter of indifference to me, what I am called,

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Very true! "That we call a roſe, by any other name wou'd ſmell as ſweet."

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Aye: Mamma.—Molly's cheek colours like a roſe—but you bluſh like a red cabbage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Then, Miſs, cou'd your humility—ſweet roſe— fragrant flower, condeſcend to duſt out my dreſſing-room?

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Now, Mamma, will you ha' done? you've made Papa too as bad as yourſelf, and now there's no ſpeaking a word before him but he comes out with a rhyme to't.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (without.) I'm juſt in time to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Mr. Allbut, is this a time for your folly?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'll leave it to Polly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Oh, very well, Sir; but I aſſure you you ſha'n't go to London again in haſte without me—A pack of your wits and geniuſſes cou'dn't take you to one of their clubs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The Namby-pampy club.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: And only one night—but you bring home ſuch a parcel of ſtuff, and wherret every body with your rhymes and your rubbiſh!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes! but when my head is ſtuck up in poet's corner, there will be rubbiſh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Mr. Allbut, you're a brewer; mind your malt and your hops.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh! you unreaſonable woman! when it was you that ſet me on, and made me even lay out ſix ſhillings at the ſtall at the corner of Chancery-lane, for Buſhe's Art of Poetry, and only to get myſelf ready at verſifications.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Yes! but, Mr. Allbut, having travell'd all over Italy in the firſt circles of faſhion, I had hopes you might turn out a poet of nature—to run extempore with a ſtring of beautiful verſes on every occaſion, as it may offer, like the charming Italian Improviſatore.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Well, I'm the great Engliſh Improviſitory.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I have heard the harmonious Metaſtaſio, the Paſtor Fido, the Goldoni—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: On his poney.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p:
I proteſt to heaven, if you don't—A pretty thing! I can't go to take an airing in my chariot to inhale the balmy odours of the roſeate ſpring, but my maid comes with her ſteps ſtately into my drawing-room, and with her delicate paws, rattles my inſtrument out of tune. This
accounts for your negligence—letting me go to the play only t'other night without a pocket-handkerchief, and when all the boxes were in tears for the ſorrows of Yarico, I was obliged to wipe my ſympathizing, moiſtened cheek in—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Cheek! Ay! that was ſo roſy-colour'd that night— huſſey, your lady was fain to twitch the tears from off it with her white kid-gloves, ſo that the finger and thumb look'd as if ſhe had been taking brazil ſnuff—that cou'dn't ſave ſome drops falling on your neck-handkerchief; what with that and your grievous face, my love, the titter went round. One lord with a blue ribbon whiſpered, "by the heavens! that lady ſitting next to the pretty well-behaved little gentleman, is Maudlin Muzzy. (Jack laughs.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (enraged) Retire! (Maria curtſeys and exit.)

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Mamma, Molly makes a better curtſey than you— you do it with a bob and a duck and ſhake yourſelf about ſo. (mimicks.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: 'Pon my word, Maſter Jack, this is moſt unpretty behaviour, Molly! Hey! (calls.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Rare times when the hen crows, and the little cock is vnot head of the flock! Willows! eh, eh!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: I'm the white legg'd chicken—Molly!—Willows! eh, eh!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Did you rub the chairs in my chamber, (to Maria.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My poor child! (aſide)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Rub chairs! my dear, that's bus'neſs for the houſemaid—you ſhould recollect that Polly was well bought up —Did you carry that corn to the mill? (to Willows.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: My dear father! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Carry corn! nay, Mr. Allbut, are there not men enough about the houſe?—Should not forget that Mr. Willows has ſeen better days—tho' now he totally depends upon our humanity.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, Sir, as Madam obſerves, one of the men in the brewery might as well do this—I have ſufficient uſe for my time over your books.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Beſides, Sir, conſider my father's years—indeed he hasn't ſtrength!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Molly, "rattle up the Piano"—'twill make us all merry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: No, Miſs; you ſha'n't ſhow off your graces to entrap the affections of my child.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I can bear all this: but to witneſs the injurious treatment my father receives, wounds me to the ſoul,

sp.speaker: Maſi. J.
sp.p: Ecod! I'll go after, and kiſs Molly's tears away. (aſide, and going.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Now, where are you going, Maſter Jack?

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Going to read a fine ſoft ſympathy book— Mamma—he! he! he! Yes, I'll kiſs Molly. (aſide, and exit.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Isn't that—Mrs. Bellevue under my roof! (looking out).

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Gad! 'tis widow Bellevue—but, love, our rooſ would ſtill be her's, but for my prudent dexterity in tricking her out of it. While her huſband, my old maſter, lived, he was ſharp over me: but, no ſooner the hatchment clapt upon the wall, than all her ancient noble blood fluſhed in her face at the ſight of the blue dragons, and the three white azure rampant fiſhing-hooks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: That ſlut Maria! tho' we pay handſomely for poor's rates to bring the paupers out of the roads and hovels.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay! Mrs. Bellevue's a poor pauper in the hovel now, yet ſhe was once too grand to have her great name poſted in ledgers—no, ſhe muſt have the buſineſs carried on under my firm, ſo rather than hurt her dignity, my little bit of an inſignificant name ſneak'd into the leaſe, glided into the conſols, ſtole into the Eaſt India ſtock, and my little bit of a ſelf popp'd into her houſe and land—like the New Church in the Strand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Yes, it's certainly Maria encourages her to come here; I dare ſay I'm cut up finely. (liſtens.) Gone into the parlour! impudence! (going.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Now for a neat rhyme! (aſide, and holding her.) Gone into the parlour, impudence—juſt like a—a— (Seems puzzled for a rhyme, and not hitting on it, holds down his head, puts his hands in his coat-pockets and runs into the houſe—Mrs. Allbut follows in a rage.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I. Allbut's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Maria and Mrs. Bellevue, with a Book.
div.p: INDEED I'm glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Once I cou'd be happy to bid you welcome here.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Aye! Mrs. Bellevue, this houle when your's, was the ſeat of politeneſs and hoſpitality—hasn't Sir Henry ſince ſent to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No, my Love, he's no more a brother. His late acquiſition of a baronet's title, which he never expected, has rais'd him ſo much above me, that I'm now out of ſight—every ſpark of fraternal affection; even compaſſion for my ſufferings has been long extinguiſhed!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I'm out of all patience with him— his family pride, ſo provokingly unreaſonable—to take ſuch a vaſt alarm at your marrying a tradeſman, when he himſelf, tho' a baronet, is ſtill in buſineſs—your huſband was a brewer —your proud brother is a banker—and where the end is money, I can't ſee any great difference in the means us'd to acquire it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Candour ſhou'd in ſome meaſure incline me to excuſe my brother, when I reflect that my preſent deſtitute ſituation is partly the conſequence of that very family pride; which in his conduct to me wears the appearance of cruelty—of inhumanity!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Aye, Madam, on the ſudden death of your worthy huſband, what a pity that you cou'dn't ſuppreſs your own ideas of rank and birth, by being above all concern for the bus'neſs, in truſting it into the hands of this deſigning fool— this knaviſh Mr. Allbut!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: A villain!—He abus'd my conſidence—I plac'd him in a truſt—and then inſtead of clearing; to puzzle and perplex—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: His purpoſe was to get all into his own power!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: He has done it—poſſeſs'd himſelf of my fortune, here—even of my houſe—and drove me to—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: The vulgar Mrs. Allbut—indeed the great lady of the village—rattling by your cottage-door in her chariot— (Mrs. Bellevue weeps.) But I'm wrong to revive in your mind—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: My kind Maria—in the bud of years; yet bloom of diſcretion!—had I then ſuch an early friend! but thoſe whom misfortune has doom'd to participate in friendſhip, only by receiving, may ſeem intereſted for a grateful mention of its ſacred bleſſings. I am poor—you have been good to me—if I thank you, you will do juſtice to my intention—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Don't grieve, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I didn't know the worth of your mind when my ſon ſet the juſt value upon your perſon and accompliſhments—He could diſcern genuine merit, I was dazzled with the blaze of tranſitory riches; and when I ſhould have bleſs'd him with a real treaſure, I wrong'd both him and you!—Forbid your union; and to prevent it for ever, ſent my child over ſeas far—far from me! Perhaps now a wand'ring fugitive. Oh! I have been wicked, cruel, unnatural! I'm puniſh'd, but not enough!—I ſhould be reſign'd—I am.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Dear Madam, all will be better—No news yet of your William?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No, my dear; and ſince the unhappy change of affairs, I ſcarce wiſh for my ſon—I have now no home to receive him—no ſmile of welcome—my bleſſing and my tears are all I've leſt to give him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: As my brother Charles was led to go abroad merely with the hopes of finding your William, they may have met; the two boys were here exemplary in their friendſhip—they may, they will afford mutual aſſiſtance ſhould either want it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: There too, from my unworthy conduct, you and your father are now deprived of comfort and protection from a brother and a ſon. Was Charles here, the Allbuts dare not treat you as they do. But I know nothing of William ſince his quitting the captain that I ſent him with, and proceeding by himſelf to the Eaſt-Indies. My Boy has a relation there in power—but no accounts from him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: My father and I remain in the ſame uncertainty —You'll ſtay and take ſome refreſhment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Excuſe me, my dear—I'll not be the cauſe of drawing Mrs. Allbut's diſpleaſure upon you.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: She never wants a cauſe for that. Step into my room—I've had a trifling preſent from ſome friends in town—I muſt beg your acceptance of a part of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: You've too much concern for me—I gave you evil, and you return every good.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: My dear Ma'am, be cheerful. (Takes her by the hand and exeunt.)

div.head: SCENE II. A Green. Enter Charles in a Sailor's Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: How every well-known object delights.—Captain Vanſluiſen!

div.p: I find you receiv'd my letter.

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: Yaw, Mynheer; and I'm com'd at de very day it bid me meet you here. My ſhip have brought you riches from Batavia, ſafe to Amſterdam, and now ſafe to London.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Pleaſure, indeed! My riches I acquired by labour, difficulty, and danger—had a hard ſtruggle for my life too, ſince, Captain—you know impatience to re-viſit England, would not ſuffer me to wait for your ſailing.

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: I did hear de littal ſhip you embark in was caſt away.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Wreck'd here on the coaſt—dead of night—had juſt time to throw on any jacket that came to hand—I got on ſhore with only life—no cath—knew nobody—diſpatch'd that letter to you, took a ſhort ſtick in my hand, puſh'd off on ſoot, and with a hale conſtitution and jovial heart, here am I returned to my dear native village, worth two hundred thouſand pounds, which ten years ago I quitted, not maſter of—

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: I did loſt all your riches at ſea, but I did found dem again—Ve vere taken by a Frenchman—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: By a Frenchman! zounds!

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: Dey did board—clapp'd us all under hatches—but van of my crew, a brave young Engliſhman, in de mid vatch, crept out of a port up de ſides of the ſhip, ſnatch up a hanger, overpower de French ſentry, releas'd us, and ve did retook our veſſel.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What, one man—Huzza! Well done little England! (takes off his hat and waves it.)

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: De capitan of de enemy was an Iriſhman— ſought like de dyvil—in deſpair to ſee his prize, gone, darted on de Engliſh boy—claſp'd him in his arm, and jump'd overboard down in de vater—a heavy ſea—cou'dn't ſlack ſail—ſaw dem no more!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My fortune preſerved by the loſs of a brave fellow leſſens the enjoyment!—My heart throbs once more to behold—Now for my father's; but firſt a rub thwart my chin, and, (looking out,) is n't this Grigſby the barber, dreſs'd very odd for a friſeur! A worthy fellow he is—there I can get—How glad am I to come home. Ah, no place like old England, not a houſe that won't fling open its doors to me; not a table without a plate, or a parlour without a nail for my hat! Bells rung! bonfires, I warrant! ch,

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Don't interrupt—I am conſidering a caſe—I love good eating. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: 1ſt Vill.
sp.p: Now the Doctor's head is ſplitting with judgement.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I muſt ingratiate myſelf with Mrs. Allbut— without her countenance I may ſhut up ſhop, and cork up my wine vaults. I take fifty pounds a year of her money for only chatting at her tea-table on Italians, Della-Cruſcas, and the nervous ſyſtem.

sp.speaker: 2d Vill.
sp.p: But, Doctor, my brother Tummas be main bad.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh! what you've a bad brother.

sp.speaker: 2d Vill.
sp.p: Sick.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: You're all impertinent. A ſine thing if I'm to have ſtudied the material medicar, Southampton-port, alder-ſloe juice, and marrow-pomatum of Pharmacopolia, Britiſh coniac, turnip-cyder of Tooley-ſtreet, malaga ſurgery, tawny bottle-cruſts, eſſence of Burganny, curling-iron and apothecaryſhip, to throw away my time and ſkill upon all the ragged muſſins o' th' place; but this is the curſe of a man's getting into reputation.

sp.speaker: 2d Vill.
sp.p: Ay, Doctor, 'cauſe you roots out a diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: So I do. I'm for none of your worthleſs radical cures.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What, has Grigſby the barber turn'd doctor apothecary?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Vill.
sp.p: Our couſin Ralph be got ſick again, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh, his malady was—I perfectly remember his caſe; he was ill of a—a—Camera Obſcura. How did you treat him?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Vill.
sp.p: Bleſs you! I can't afford to treat people. When I be's in company, every man pays his own ſhot.

sp.speaker: 3d Vill.
sp.p: Doctor, my ſon George that liſted for a ſoger— I got un off, but he's now at huome ſick on my hands.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: As we of the faculty ſay, much depends on diet. What's his regimen?

sp.speaker: 3d Vill.
sp.p: The old Buffs.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: The devil! I mean what does he eat!

sp.speaker: 3d. Vill.
sp.p: He's fond of eggs for breakfaſt, and—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Stop. What does he do with the ſhells?

sp.speaker: 3d. Vill.
sp.p: The ſhells—let's ſee, (pauſing) ecod, I think he throws 'em behind the fire.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: There 'tis! How the devil can a man expect health that throws his egg-ſhells behind the fire? Here, (writes with his pencil on a bit of paper) he's a little deafiſh.

sp.speaker: 3d Vill.
sp.p: Yes, with all the drumming—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Then we muſt twiddle up his optic nerve; (writes) ſcrupolorum Glaubers, vermifuge, ſquills, ay—As he's your ſon you muſt give him ſal. prunell, ſal. polychreſt, and ſal. almonic.

sp.speaker: 3d Vill.
sp.p: Yes: but the damn'd dog will be always running after Sal. Johnſon.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: My boy will mix that up for you, (giving the paper.) You'll pay him half a crown. Confuſe it in a baſon of water—in that let him throw his egg-ſhells, and after ſhaking the bottle, fling bowl and all out at—mind—the ſtreet-window—that may get me another patient, (aſide,) firſt conſulting the thermometer. Begone! I'll give no more advice this morning.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Vill.
sp.p: Ay, Doctor, times are turn'd—You don't mind poor folks now you've got a broken-knee'd mare, and a new old whiſkey.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Broken-knee'd mare—old whiſkey—ah, no chance of being look'd on till I ſtep into my chariot.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Is this our village?

div.stage: Enter a Servant in a Livery.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, my maſter—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p:
(ſmiling and cringing.) What, is your maſter taken ill? Dear gentleman! I'll run to him. (Aſide.) He
pays me thirty pounds a year, and won't venture out in a morning till I come and tell him which way the wind lies.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Sir; but he deſires you'll ſend him in a dozen of your beſt old port.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Ha!—What my black ſtrap?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A wine-merchant too!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Very well. (Exit ſervant.) When he drinks my port he'll ſoon want ſomething out of my ſhop. My red ſeal bottles, always bring one with a long cravat round his neck.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Now, Captain, you'll ſee how glad he'll be to find I'm return'd. My father was a good friend to him; and now for a ſpecimen of gratitude and early faithful attachment. Ah, honeſt Grigſby—your hand, my old lad.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Rather free. (drawing back.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Stop!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Stop!—any buſineſs with me, maſter? (looks ſtrange).

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Don't you remember Charley Willows?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What, is it you? Come home in rags—this is the fuſs made about him by his family! I ſaid how 'twou'd be, (aſide—ſurveying Charles with contempt,) hem— (going.) Whoſe chariot? (looking out.) Oh! Madam, your moſt profound humble ſervant (bows off obſequiouſly.) Smart gig that! How d'ye do, Sir? (bows off more familiar.) A good ſtout gelding!—hows goes it Mr.— (nodds off ſlightly.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well, Grigſby! Youv'e done this dev'liſh well. I was going to your ſhop for a rub and a ſcrub—you always had a little ſoap and water!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Scrubs come to my houſe for ſoap and water.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How! (with ſurpriſe and indignation.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (Aſide, not regarding him.) This fellow's ſiſter Maria tho', is pretty—but then, that Miſs Louiſa—a report that ſhe's daughter, or ſomewhat to a lord—wasn't it?— an odd myſtery that—hiding at Jollyboy's—poor tho', and tisn't what were you, but what are you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Grigſby!— (angry.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p:
(ſmiling placid and contemptuous, takes ſnuff.) Madam Allbut is my firſt object and attention—eh, is n't that Squire Hedgworth and young Briers going out ſhooting? A preſent of ſome game for Mrs. Allbut might—one ſhou'd never make preſents but to them that can afford to buy— How faſhionable they're equip'd for the ſport! I muſt kick
up a rummage in my old maſter's wardrobe—ſee if it can't afford me a ſmart ſhooting-jacket; every gentleman in the country ſhould ſhoot—hey, my glove, (ſearches.) A phyſician to feel pulſes ſhou'd have his hand warm, ſoft, and white— my hand (diſplays it) 'till I can ſport the chariot, ſhou'd get a muff—a ring—my ſweet old patient found dead with with a brace of guineas clench'd in his fiſt—ready ſee for the doctor—the punctual honeſt ſoul!—the old nurſe and I dividing I ſhou'dn't have given her half—the two wou'd have compaſs'd a ſmart ring, ha!—hum!

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: He's gone to ſet de "plate of pudden for you, and knock up de peg for your hat."

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This a ſample of my welcome!

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: I tink I hear "de bells ringing"—I long for "de bonfire."

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Damn the village! I wiſh 'twas on fire—but hold, there may be only one Grigſby in it. Yes, 'twas certainly my forlorn appearance! the raſcal thinks I'm come home poor.

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: If you had, mynheer Villows, you ſee your welcome!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Aye: but unjuſt to draw a concluſion from the behaviour of this low-born murdering mountebank. (A ſhot heard at ſome diſtance.)

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: (without.) You've certainly wing'd her.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (looking out.) Oh, now you'll ſee a different affair. Here are a couple of gentlemen, my former ſchool-fellows, who, except Willy Bellevue, whom to follow abroad I firſt left my home, were my moſt particular and intimate companions.—Yes, 'tis—

div.stage: Enter Briers and Hedgeworth, (with fowling pieces.)

sp.speaker: Hedg.
sp.p: I think it fell in the marſh.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: No getting it without wetting one's ſelf, and I've no great wiſh for Dr. Grigſby's ſtuff—hey, Nero! (whiſtles) if I don't ſhoot that dog! badly made, good for nothing, (perceiving Charles.) Oh, here, you ſir, leap the hedge and bring me the bird—it fell yonder—damn the fellow, how he ſtares! Oh, he muſt be paid beforehand—there— (flings halfpence on the ground) Now, hey over!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: My dear Bob Hedgeworth, how d'ye do?—Nick Briers! here I am come home to you again (they look at each other, then at Charles with ſtrangeneſs.)

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: De gentlemen ſeems to have forgotten you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Aye, I am ſunburn'd and weatherbeaten—but, my boys, don't you remember Charley Willows?

sp.speaker: Hedg.
sp.p: (to Briers—charging his gun.) Do you recollect?— I ſhall be out of powder.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Oh, yes, very well—It's the—the—poh! Willows —aye, brother to the pretty girl there below, at—Allbut, the brewer's.—My lad, if you don't take care you will be preſs'd.

sp.speaker: Hedg.
sp.p: Nick. you ſhou'd give the poor devil ſomething. I remember his ſiſter was always your partner at the aſſembly at Guildford.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well, but lads—what news?—I hav'n't even ſeen my father yet.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Free and eaſy—any thing of a former acquaintance got down out of one's line—a curſed boar—no ſhaking off.

div.stage: Enter Grigſby in a ſhooting dreſs (accoutred.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your moſt obedient—

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: (hollowing out.) Oh, dem'me, here's the doctor too.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (charging.) I've forgot wadding—oh! my head! 'pon my ſoul, gentlemen, I was going to charge with a bank note—oh! doctor Boerhaave's proſcription—cou'dn't read it—but no matter—the mixture is gone home and the patient will ſoon follow it, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Ma'am, this is the ſhorteſt way to our mill.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Aye! my good Margery, your character of Mrs. Allbut has ſo frighten'd me, that I believe I muſt ſojourn with you a little longer; how ſhall we get by theſe gentlemen? I wiſh they wouldn't ſhoot till we are paſt.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (apart to Louiſa) Oh, Ma'am, want your change— hav'n't ſo much in the till—ſend you in a choice cheſt of florence. (To Briers and Hedgeworth, ſmiling,) Gentlemen, will you permit me to make one in your very ſalubrious amuſement?—I promis'd ſome game to a lady—I'm an excellent ſhot—mark, (preſents.)

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Stop, Ma'am! Duce o' that doctor!

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Zounds, doctor—that's a cow!—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p:
That a cow! I know it, my dear Sir; but don't you ſee the little bird perched on the top of her horn?—my game has hopp'd the twig—it's wiſe —for, gentlemen, reſt is the nurſe of diſeaſe, "You ſee as a doctor, I ſpeak againſt my own intereſt; nothing but exerciſe and open air can brace and ſtrengthen the animal
functions, and when the caninus rabies, which we of the faculty, call vertigo in the foot, comes; reſt brings a polyphus in the lungs, ſymptomatic of the epigaſtic region; and then nothing better than ſudorific antimony, parſimony, and ready money, diſmembering the whole animal oeconomy with the ſyrrup of wild pop"— (Briers fires cloſe at his cars— be runs off.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ah! (ſhricking.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Frighten a lady! (ſnatches the piece from Briers, and throws it over the bedge) "Hey over!"

sp.speaker: Briers.
sp.p: Dem me, what do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh, I'll tell you. (Briers taking Hedgeworth under the arm, they both ſing and walk off.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Thoſe are our young men of faſhion, devoid of breeding or humanity!—and this ſpirited young man— You're a gallant fellow! Thoſe brutal wretches! Oh, what miſtakes Fortune does make in the diſtribution of her gifts! (aſide)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A lovely creature! But why did I not ſpeak to her? Thoſe puppies raſcally conduct has ſtupefied me!— Charming girl!—The ſcoundrels! (pauſes and looks confuſed.)

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: And theſe ſcoundrels were your intimate companions? Why, Mynheer Villows, you did keep good company!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This my reception—the joys I promiſed myſelf! They certainly imagine I'm come home pennyleſs—'tis plain, if I had, how 'twou'd be.

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: Ah, Mynheer Villows, dis is your home!— Ah, ha! a man may love his own country vidout crowing over dat of another,

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why true, Captain. It is not this or that ſpot that ſtamps the character; Nature will not change for climate, cuſtoms, or complexion: the villain, black or white, is of one nation, and the benevolent are fellow countrymen, though born at the extremities of the globe— Yes, Briers and Hedgeworth's ſcorn, all to my ſeeming poverty!

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: Suppoſe den you ſeem to be poor, only to prove which of your friends deſerve to be better'd by your riches.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Thank ye, I will. A moſt excellent thought!— my dreſs too ſo lucky—Oh, but Captain, my property is conſigned to the banking-houſe, Sir Henry Check.

sp.speaker: Capt. Van.
sp.p: Yaw.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then, maſter of a princely fortune, I'll ſally through the village in my old trowſers—Is that a good ſhipwreck'd, rueful phiz? (looks dejected.) Come, Captain.

div.head: SCENE III. Before an elegant Villa.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Can't kill a bird. Juſt as I cover mark, and touch trigger, damn it, I always ſhut the wrong eye—How to pay court to Mrs. Allbut—

div.stage: Enter a Man in a Soldier's Coat, with a Muſquet and Wallet.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What a ſap was I to come this way, juſt under Mr. Allbut's noſe, and he's a juſtice of peace! (Sees Grigſby, endeavours to hide the wallet, and ſneak by.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: That fellow's been poaching: ſince I cannot bring down game with lead, I'll try ſilver. Ho, you infernal damn'd dog! I know you're a poacher, deſtroying the nobleman's game, you vile thief! Give up what you've got!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Zounds, I ſhall go to quod for my marauding!— Maſter, don't hurt a poor man with a family.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: This is a lucky ſtroke—our great Madam Allbut will eſteem this ſuch a prodigious compliment—beſides the credit of ſhooting ſo capital—Well, ſay nothing of this bus'neſs—there, I buy your game, (gives him money, and takes the wallet.) [Exit Man.] Here's Allbut, and I hav'n't time to put the birds into my net.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: So, Doctor, in viſiting your patients, you ſhoot by the way?—'gad, that's killing two birds with one ſtone.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Yes, Sir, I've had tolerable ſport—I've ſhav'd a good many birds.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You've been ſhaving the birds?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Hem—I mean killing—powder-puff and waſhball—that is, powder and ball—ſhot—I've brought here the produce of my ſucceſs humbly to preſent to Mrs. Allbut.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha! You're right to make preſents; ſhe's in a high paſſion—but this politeneſs of your's will ſoften her.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Allbut from the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Lock'd themſelves up! This audacious Mrs. Bellevue to dare to come into a houſe of mine!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: My love, here's our worthy friend Doctor Grigſby has been ſhooting this morning early, and he begs you'll accept of a few birds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Shooting is a cruel ſport! the pretty innocent feather'd tenants of the air—the tuneful minſtrels that wake the roſy morn with carols ſweet—it ſhocks me!—my feelings are perhaps too exquiſite.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Feeling! Yes, my love, and your taſte is not bad— over a roaſt pheaſant! We ſhall have a nice ſupper. Doctor, you'll come and eat a morſel of your own good cheer?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Do pray, Doctor. (curtſies.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Madam, I ſhall do myſelf that honour.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A few partridges here, eh, Doctor?—and ſome woodcocks? (taking up the wallet.) Oh, you fear'd they'd break your net.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I truſt, Ma'am, theſe dainties will ſuit the delicacy of your ladyſhip's palate. (Bows.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (opens the wallet.) What the devil, a gooſe!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Ha! (ſurpriſed and confuſed.) Ay, a wild gooſe!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: "Here's the pretty innocent feather'd tenant of the air"—By the Lord, here's a wild pig!—"Here's the little bird that wakes the roſy morn with carols ſweet!"

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (confuſed.) By the heavens, this muſt have been done by the magic lantern!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Thank ye, Doctor—but rather too light food for ſupper. However, as you're our apothecary, it's very well intended.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Sir, be aſſur'd you ſhall not affront your betters.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Affront! Let me tell you, Madam, we of the faculty think that my preſent is wholeſome and good eating —ſo ſays Doctors Boerhaave, Crook Shanks, Cheney, and Sir John Pringle.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes,—but, Doctor, damn me if here isn't a wild old woman's petticoat—Why, inſtead of giving, you're come here to make game! (Grigſby ſteals off.) Holla, Doctor, does Johnny Pringle recommend this for good eating?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: An audacious villain! Peter! (calling.)

But I muſt compoſe my mind with divine poeſy: (takes up paper, and reads,) "Seraphic ſouls ſublime, celeſtial food,
ſoft circumambient air"—I deſire, Mr. Allbut, you'll have him turn'd out of the pariſh, next Veſtry—Tell the cook that's for dinner to-morrow. (Pointing.)

div.stage: Peter takes up the wallet, and exit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No, my love, we've company to-morrow—piggy looks ſo nice, we'll keep it till we're by ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Something elſe to think on than Doctor Grigſby's vagaries—and you to join—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Love, inſtead of ſnubbing, you ſhou'd take care of me—give me nice cordials, to make me live long; for, once you're a widow, as I did with Mrs. Bellevue, ſome ſmart rogue will come and jockey you out of all. Aye, now I'm briſk—but when I'm flat—dead—you'll be for marrying ſome flaſhy young gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I deſire, Mr. Allbut, you'll not flatter me with ſuch hopes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Of two ſuch popes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Huſh! They've broke up their conſultation.

div.stage: Enter Maria and Mrs. Bellevue from the Houſe. Mr. and Mrs. Allbut ſteal in, and ſhut the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Bleſs you, my dear Miſs; my kind, good angel!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Farewell, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: What muſt have become of me but for you?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Nay, now, indeed—

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: If heav'n has a ſtore for the benevolent, your comforts will be many. You nor your's were never obliged to me—you owe nothing, but give all. Your conduct, contraſted with the ungrateful poſſeſſors of this houſe—for they have ſhared my bounty—they roſe high upon my ruins, tho' now they will not know me. When we'd win the heart by increaſe of favours, each added obligation but renders the claim of benevolence more inſupportable; and, though a kind wiſh is the only return expected, pride often quits the debt by an ungenerous endeavour to diſown it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Dear Madam, be cheerful—the Allbuts are unworthy of your reſentment: their repeated cruelties to my father and me cancel what they compliment by the name of charity—we muſt bear. If my father receives any news from abroad, you ſhall hear—and you'll do the ſame by us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: Aye; was my William returned—the letters you have received from Charles, tho' long back, never once mention him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Be aſſur'd, Madam, William is ſtill here, (points to her breaſt;) but why ſhould I flatter myſelf he has yet a heart for me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: If he lives, dear Maria, could his gen'rous, his faithful heart make a reparation for paſt injuries! Perhaps in my boy's honeſt affection you may forget the unkindneſs of his mother—Ch; that I could atone!—in that ſweet hope, his return will give me the firſt delight—Well, well—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Come, all will be well. If I can ſlip out, I'll bring you ſome newſpapers—they'll amuſe you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: I thank you; I'll ſend my little Edward for them, if I can prevail upon him—oh, here he is—my child! —now look, isn't Edward ſhooting up very like your—I beg your pardon—his brother, my dear William.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: (tender.) Edward, how d'ye do, my dear?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Very well, I'm oblig'd to you. Mamma, you ſtaid ſo long, I fear'd Mr. Allbut had affronted you, and I'd have aſk'd him what he meant by it?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Why, that's very valiant of you, Edward—but t'other day, when Maſter Jack affronted you, you cry'd and walk'd away.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Aye, I didn't mind for myſelf, 'cauſe Maſter Jack was able to beat three of me; but I wou'dn't ſuffer the biggeſt man in England to affront my mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: My child, my love, come, we'll go home.— (Going towards the houſe.)

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why, Mamma, we don't live in the great houſe now—Mamma forgets our home now is the cottage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. B.
sp.p: True, my love (ſtruggling with her tears.)

div.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Bellevue, Edward, and Maria.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I. Before Allbut's houſe (enter Maria, goes to a ſide door and puſhes.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I LEFT the door open—ſome of Maſter Jack's tricks, I ſuppoſe, (knocks, Mrs. Allbut appears at the window.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh! (looking up) the door ſhut whilſt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: The Maria! I proteſt I didn't know you—to pay me a viſit! this is an honor—I—but I don't imagine you've any very material buſineſs here, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: There was indeed a ſervant girl I had—one Molly Willows—but ſhe got ſo pert and idle—I am determined never to let her into my houſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: But, Ma'am, ſure you won't—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Can't avoid it, Miſs. (Maria weeps.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: They ſaid our ſmart Doctor Grigſby came this way—walk off with the money I had to pay my rent! (looking about.) No! holla! Madam Allbut! do your folks intend to bring that ſack of corn up to-day? mayhap you don't bake your own bread any more; becauſe if you want the flour, ſend the griſt up to mill, tol, lol, lol, (ſings.) Miſs Willows, what's the matter with my pretty chick? If it's a man has made you cry—tell me who—I'll ſee if I can't duſt his jacket, and if it's a woman, I'll tell her ſhe's a damn'd hell-cat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Then you're a buſy fool.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Becauſe the air's ſo cool.

div.stage: (Mrs. Allbut ſeems to ſit and read.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Turn'd, poor ſoul, into the ſtreet! Ecod, Madam ſeems very eaſy after doing an action a Grand Turk wou'd be aſham'd of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: "In tranquil hours it gave the ſmile ſerene." (reading.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (at the other window.) You I have not ſeen, (To Jollyboy.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I deſire, girl, you will not bring a mob about my houſe.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Am I a mob?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: For you I've a job.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: No doing any thing for this man. (Retires.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To grind my corn—but beware of the horn. (Mrs, Allbut appears at the ſame window with Allbut.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Come in I deſire.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I beg leave to retire, (he draws in—ſhe takes his place at the window, and is going to ſpeak—he puts his head over her ſhoulder) I'll go ſit at the fire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (to Maria.) Contrary to my commands, you brought Widow Bellevue to my houſe, and be aſſur'd that you ſhall find my door for ever ſhut. (Shuts window and retires.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Turn'd out for relieving the diſtreſſed—poor ſoul! too good to be ſhelter'd by a houſe, and now her roof is the canopy of heaven! Miſs Louiſa, our lodger, has left us—might again let the little box—but was it to bring me a guinea a day—I'd rather you'd occupy it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I'm obliged to you, but cannot think of—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I'd be no loſer by the bargain; for proſperity hangs over the houſe that contains a humane and charitable heart.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Whither turn—ſeparated from my father! leave him with thoſe cruel people!

sp.speaker: M. Jack.
sp.p: Molly! hark'ee—

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: (joyful.) Has your Mamma, relented? Has ſhe ſent for me?

sp.speaker: M. Jack.
sp.p: Oh, no, my dear; but I'm ſoftened into a power of compaſſion for you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why now that's well—I always ſaid Maſter Jack was the flower of the ſlock—you think Miſs has been badly treated, and pity her, eh?

sp.speaker: M. Jack.
sp.p: Yes, I pity her. My dear, ſince Mamma has diſcharged you—ſooner than you ſhou'd come to want— if you abide at Mrs. Bellevue's cottage; I'll pay her a ſhilling a week, and give you half-a-crown now and then, if you'll only let me come and kiſs you at all times when I'm in a humour?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: How! (with indignation.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why you ungenerous hound! is that your pity? Do you come and affront her with your raſcally propoſals at the very time that her ſorrowful ſituation renders her an object of reſpect and protection?

sp.speaker: M. Jack.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Dick Jollyboy! I'll protect you with a douſe o'th' chops.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: You whelp! (ſtrikes him.)

sp.speaker: M. Jack.
sp.p: (crying.) Oh, that's pretty uſage to your landlord's ſon—ſee if I don't make Mamma turn you out of your mill—fine doings! a young gentleman to be dous'd only for aſking to keep a Miſs! Exit blubb'ring.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Keep a miſs! pretty buck! no wonder curs like you, when the tip-top of the nation ſet before you decent examples.—My dear you'll be ſafer in my little cottage than in this great houſe.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: I believe you—I accept your kindneſs, and thank you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why now that's hearty!

div.stage: Enter Grigſby, full dreſſed, with large wig, muff, and cane.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Tho' I was deceived, by that foraging ſon of a Scarlet fever, yet my preſent was as ſweetly aſtringent as rough Alicant—I'll ſhew theſe good people that a Phyſician is ſomebody. I ſee reſpect is all paid to appearance; and by heav'ns I'll have a chariot tho' it draws me to St George's Fields, hem; (looks important.) Young woman,—this girl loves me (aſide)—Is your maſter or miſtreſs at home?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: She has no maſter or miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: How old are you? (to Jollyboy.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why? ſuppoſe I'm three and forty—what then?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: You're not a phyſician?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, thank heav'n.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Then you're a fool.—Every man at forty is either a fool or a phyſician. (Struts.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: (to Jollyboy.) I think I ſhall put you to inconvenience—ſuppoſe I go to the Doctor's, till I ſee what father determines.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Come to me! oh! this is what we call love-powder. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Hold, Miſs. Doctor, give me a ten pound note.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Give you a ten pound note?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes; that Miſs Louiſa gave you.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: So, when my patients give me a ſee, I muſt give it to you? ha, ha, ha! but I'm not to laugh. (Looks grave.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come—ten pounds!—touch!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A touch—in the pericranky—bid he bite you? (to Maria.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No: nor you ſhan't bite me. Give me the ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: He's got the hydrofogy! bring me out a baſon of water. (to Maria.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Never mind either ſoap or water—I'm ſhav'd already—but return the money, or I'll take up your old trade and dreſs your wig upon your own block—here's my little twiggling comb! (Shakes his cudgel.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A Robbery!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: A fellow loarns to bleed upon the veins of a cabbage leaf, and draws teeth, by clapping a red-hot poker to our noſes!—muſt pick our pocket as a wine-merchant and a doctor with ſloc-juice and powder of poſt. Deliver! (Shakes his cudgel, and Grigſby gives the note.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Witneſs, Miſs; on the King's highway he ſays "ſtop, Sir, ſtand and deliver!"

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Jollyboy, this is a very dangerous practice, and what nobody could believe from a man of your character—oh! my poor dear father! (Looking out and exit.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Jollyboy, Mrs. Allbut has order'd me to treat you like a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ah; you'll find it eaſy to obey her!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How dare you abuſe my wife and beat my child?— I'll give you—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: This is quarter day, and there's your rent, (gives the note to Allbut.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'll give you a—receipt.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No: my word is a voucher that I have paid you— tol, lol.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What an honeſt man!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Honeſt! this is the moſt barefac'd, impudent, way of paying rent! "An honeſt man" is plunder'd, and you are the receiver.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Plunder'd!—is this your way of making preſents?— if you've got at robbing hedges and hen-rooſts, your old practices, my boy;—how dare you make me the receiver?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: By heav'ns, Sir; I'm of a ſanguine and aduſt complexion, and—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: 'Sblood, Sir, who cares for your duſty complexion!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Return it, for at preſent—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'll not return the preſent—the gooſe is pluck'd— the pig is ſcalded, and damn me, if you ſhall have any thing back, but the old woman's petticoat.

div.stage: Enter Shopman with a packet of bottles.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Maſter, I'm going to take the medicine to—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Take medicine—zounds! take ten pounds from that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: (ſtaring) Sir!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Take ten pounds from me?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: If he won't give up it quietly, trip up his heels.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Trip up my heels! touch me, and I'll lay you by the heels in a jail, (runs in.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Never mind—if he does, I'll viſit you.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Thank'ee, Sir, but I'll ſave you the trouble.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: He ſhall reſtore it, elſe—it's quite opake and clear to me—I'll oſſify his very hones—a miller and brewer take and give my money, hand to fiſt! enough to diſlocate my brain-pan—but that my wrongs brought out the loving concern of that comely ſervantmaid, Maria—my money! oh! by the—as I'm now bemuff'd and bewig'd, I muſt ſupport the condign dignity of a phyſician.—hum! ha!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ay; it's a bad world, I ſee that. My thread-bare jacket drives every body away from me—ſome look with pity—ſome with contempt—but not one offers to relieve me!—oh! this is Mrs. Bellevue.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (within.) Give you ten pounds you barberizing raſcal! out with him, Peter! (Peter and Allbert ſeen at door thruſting Grigſby out.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Here's a diaſcordium!—here's a noſtrum!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And a roſtrum—and a cuff—and a muff— (kick out the muff and ſhuts the door.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A new thing—people turn'd out of Mrs. Bellevne's houſe! why it's our gen'rous doctor!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Here's ptiſan and diet drink—they took me by the noſe!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well: that's only returning your former compliments—you've got a ſcratch, but you've your own ſhop.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I never take any thing out of my own ſhop.

sp.speaker: Maſter J.
sp.p: Oh, ho! Father and Peter have been having fine ſport here—kicking Doctor Grigſby out, and never call'd me to join in the fun, oh,—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Pounded crabs-eyes! (Maſter Jack gives him a blow on the back and runs in.)—Had my man but back'd me—he ſhall never again pound mortar of mine—my lad, you may want employ, as your father and ſiſter are—beſides his ſiſter loves me, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What! ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: You can carry out parcels—I have been ſprain'd and batter'd like opodeldoc—no cutaneous hurt—but quite external—it has put me into ſuch a rage, I mean the Illiac paſſion and woe to Panado!—look at my caput— is n't there a fracture in the abdomen?—its denſe as a feather—oh, buſineſs for Bow-ſtreet—patients—I muſt now viſit the Brown-bear. Cure from my own ſhop! may do for a porter, but you'll never make an apothecary, oh, no,—no, no, (Picks up the muff, adjuſts his wig and cloaths.) the law ſhall—to give me ſuch a diameter on my noſe! I'll conſult Mr. Fudge the attorney, he ſhall take out a ſuperſuijet—follow me!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What does he mean by my father and ſiſter? carry out parcels—porter—ſcoundrel! but tho' the people here thought me poor; yet they might ſuppoſe my father wou'd inſtantly repleniſh my purſe—he, thank heaven, can't be ſubject to their glum froſty looks—he has competence, and I hope health. Enter Willows, from an out-office, carrying a ſmall ſack full, which he immediately lays down. Is not that my father?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I ſhall never be able of myſelf— (looking out, ſees Maria.) My child! I muſt not grieve her! I muſt ſeem to make light of it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Nobody dare diſobey Mr. Allbut's orders to carry it for him, nor ſhou'd I add to his grief by telling him their uſage to me—now, Sir, don't attempt it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Child, we're now ſervants to Mr. Allbut, and to eat his bread and neglect our duty, is diſhoneſt and ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Servants to Mr. Allbut! reduced indeed! oh, this accounts fully for my reception here.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Sir, I fear 'twill hurt you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My beloved ſiſter—brought up with tenderneſs!— my kind parent!—are theſe the comforts of his age!— but then isn't it in my power to—oh! till this moment, I never taſted the ſweets of riches! the delightful reflection that I can make others happy!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Sir, indeed you can't. (Helping Willows to lift the ſack on a pitching-block.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: They don't ſeem to know me. (In a broad blunt voice.) How d'ye do, Sir?—ſervant Miſs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: How d'ye do? how d'ye do?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Seem paſt your labour?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, my lad; but thoſe that wo'n't labour may be compell'd to do worſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Have you now no ſon to work a little for you in your old days?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why I may have a ſon abroad, but perhaps my poor boy finds work hard enough himſelf.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Where was this to go?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Only up to the mill yonder—kind Sir, (curtſeys) Lord if he wou'd (aſide, joyful.) (Charles whips up the ſack and ſtalks off ſinging) then bleſſings on you! (looking after him with delight.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now, child, this is very indiſcreet—how d'ye know who this man may be?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: He's poor certainly—but he's an Engliſh ſailor, and an honeſt fellow, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Holloa! Maſter!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: (looking out.) You're right, Sir, there's the windmill, (points.)

div.head: SCENE II. The outſide of a windmill.
div.stage: Enter Charles and Margery, from the mill.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It is the dear ſoul, and I hav'n't pack'd up her things. (Goes in, Charles retires.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Well, 'tis certainly very good of him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Now wasn't it, Madam? (looking towards Charles.) Oh, then he has left it,

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (ſurpriſed.) Why that's he—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How beautiful! my experiment don't require looking ſo very bad—may rub the duſt off my face— 'tho the doctor refus'd me; yet old Margery has ſoap and water.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: The very delightful young man that interpos'd when thoſe rude gentlemen—and, here now, to aſſiſt the weak and aged! one wou'd think he watch'd for occaſions of rendering ſervices where moſt wanted—what an excellent heart muſt he have!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Don't you think, Ma'am, if well dreſs'd— really I believe he's very handſome!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, have a care! young women muſt never think men handſome—nothing more dangerous to our peace—alas! I feel it ſo. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Well, Ma'am; I'll ſtep down and apprize Mrs. Bellevue of the honor you intend her.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I thank you. This very atrocious circumſtance you've told me of the miller has confirm'd my determination to abide no longer with him.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Madam, it aſtoniſhed me! his conduct wou'd make one ſuſpect that the honeſty of the world exiſts only in appearance.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You believe he's and ſome—how very weak and inconſiderate is our ſex!—that girl now muſt be filly to take ſuch notice of men—to my fancy, if I dare have a fancy, he's the moſt amiable perſon I ever ſaw. (Looking.)
My heart beats quick—I tremble—I wiſh I—had never ſeen him—he has been making himſelf look more agreeable—now that is really very malicious. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt obedient, (bows reſpectful.) I'd talk a thouſand things, and yet I don't know what to ſay (aſide)—Ma'am, here within is great lamentation—your intention of removing will break the heart of your poor old landady.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I'm not going far, Sir—only to Mrs. Bellevue's there, below—look, Sir, that—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (aſide.) Looking quite the wrong way.—Sir, it's —Lud! what am! about? abſolutely making an aſſignation!—I fear I'm farther gone than I thought I was (aſide)—I thank you, Sir, for the concern you took in my fright this morning.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am; no merit of mine; concern for a lady who muſt intereſt all that ſee her is involuntary. (bows.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (curtſeys.) Since my coming here, I've ſauntered a good deal about, but don't recollect having ever had the pleaſure of ſeeing—lately come Sir? been abroad, I preſume?—but don't anſwer me. You ſee women will be impertinent.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: They will be charming, and men be captivated— oh, you moſt lovely—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: What! Sir— (looks cold and ſerious)—I deſerve this, (aſide.)—Sir, I retract all the information I gave you juſt now, (ſmiles archly)—people tell me, and it may be ſo, that often I don't know what I'm ſaying; yet pray don't you now by a contrary meaning take an interpretation of heart.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you have a heart?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I'm afraid not, (aſide thoughtful.) I thought I told you, you wer'n't to mind what I ſay—I'm not going to live yonder—look there (points) I ſhall never walk through that meadow in an evening—I deſire not to know if your heart is engag'd to the young maiden for whoſe old father you carried the corn to the mill. (Aſide.) Lud! if I hav'n't got to flirtation with a man I know nothing about! I the niece to a peer! and he—but love is a moſt cruel democrat! murders all diſtinction, and levels hearts by exaltation to a mutual equality of ſweet affection!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Now who is ſhe?—good and charming! and that's a volume!— (looking out.) Isn't this Allbut's wife? the miſtreſs of my father and ſiſter! who when I went abroad was little more than—what tricks has fortune been at?—Oh, my new valet—

div.p: Well, John, the people at the Roſe don't ſuſpect you belong to me?

sp.speaker: Valet.
sp.p: Oh, no, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Right, for if I've a welcome from a foul here, it ſhan't be for my riches.

sp.speaker: Valet.
sp.p: Sir, Captain Vanſluiſen bid me tell you that Sir Henry Check wiſhes to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Very well; (Exit ſervant.) but I'll be a poor fellow for another five minutes—yes; (looking out.) Mrs. Allbut. I'll try what effect my out-at-elbows has upon her.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Allbut in a rage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I don't know what's come to all the common people!—an impudent miller to dare ſtrike a ſon of mine! but paying his rent ſhan't cajole me as it has done Mr. Allbut.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (advances.) Ah, Mrs. Allbut! How d'ye do, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Who is this fellow?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (aſide.) Oh, ho!—I hope my father and ſiſter are well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I proteſt it's Young Willows—come home a beggar as I expected!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I've been very unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Unfortunate indeed! to return in this plight— where is this man?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes; but if my friends here are only ſo good as to aſſiſt me with a few comfortable meals, and a little money to ſupply me with decent clothes, I might ſoon be able to go out again and make another trial.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: The impertinence of ſuch people— (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sorry to hear my family is fallen ſo much to decay; however it's not loſt what a friend gets—glad to find you've ſince got ſo much up in the world—I hope for your kindneſs—aſham'd to appear about this figure, a few guineas wou'd rig me handſome; then I ſhould not diſgrace your table.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: My table! guineas! my friend, I never meddle in the pariſh affairs; but I fancy, if you've no viſible means of a livelihood, that the beadle knows his duty.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Me! Beadle! Madam, I hop'd for a kinder reception—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Do you ſuppoſe that Mr. Allbut is keeper of the workhouſe?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Workhouſe! the time has been when you thought it the higheſt honor, my father's even hinting at a marriage between my ſiſter and your ſon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I ſhall burſt with rage!—Yet really—ha, ha, ha! its diverting—pray, friend, ſtand a little farther off, ha, ha, ha! my table! the elegant and ſelect circle of literature, my faſhionable friends might indeed ſtare to ſee a Naples Lazaroni ſit at my table—this creature too I ſuppoſe, "plays the Piano," and "reads Sterne."

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am; but "the recording angel has no tears for you."

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
