sp.p: Oh, Mr. Allbut, here's the pleaſanteſt thing! This ragged man has a ſiſter, and expected you'd give our ſon in marriage to her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: His ſiſter marry—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Yes, our ſon Jack.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He deſerves a whack. Who is he, my dear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A
sp.p: Oh, it's that—Molly, our maid's brother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What Charley Willows, that went to ſea after Willy Bellevue?—poor man, ſeems bad times with you! My dear, he may have the run of the kitchen for a week?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Maria, now you've time, ſee will you exhibit your airs and graces at your piano forte?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then, Ma'am, no pity for my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Pray take your diſtreſſes ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Don't you know me, ſiſter? Father! (kneels.]

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, it's my brother! Heavens! I not to know him before!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My dear, dear boy, riſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Ah, lord! he can't ſpoil his clothes! Ha, ha, ha! Such folks pretend to feeling, its really amuſing!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Well, Charles, eh? how, juſt arriv'd?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Father, though I didn't go abroad rich, I'm come home poorer.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Never mind, my boy,—better bring home an empty pocket than a bad conſcience. If you're clear of caſh, I hope you're likewiſe free from diſhonour.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Heard any thing of William Bellevue?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Are we to ſtand all day lift'ning to their diſmal ſtories?—Abſolutely their croaking has an effect upon one's ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And I hope upon your heart. You once yourſelves felt the bitterneſs of poverty, and a ſympathiſing recollection might now incline you to pity ours. (Taking off his hat.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Mr. Allbut, have you got any ſilver?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A ſhilling—hem, I've got a ſixpence. If there's no hole in your hat, let it hold that. (Drops it in his bat, Maria, with an air of dignity, takes it out, and places the hut on Charles's head.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p:
A very elegant chariot ſtopp'd yonder (looks out)—ſome viſit to us—Lord, Mr. Allbut, pray come
a little farther—Willows, you're ſon is abſolutely a diſgrace! I deſire he mayn't be ſeen hov'ring about our houſe. Enter Footman in a ſull Dreſs, mourning livery. I ſaw your maſter give the meſſage for us. (Footman paſſes Allbut, walks up to Charles, bows reſpectful, and preſents a card.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (reads aloud.) "Sir Henry Check's compliments to Mr. Willows, congratulates him on his arrival in England, hopes—

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: Sir, my maſter himſelf is coming to you—but 'tis here I'm to inquire for this Lady Louiſa. (Goes into mill.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Dear! I vow it's Sir Henry Check! (apart.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mrs. Bellevue's proud brother, that won't know her—he's a K. B. and an M. P. fiddle de dee—bravo! (Walks up joyful.)

div.stage: Enter Sir Henry Check in mourning, and re-enter Footman.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: (whiſpers Sir H.) Sir, a young lady of the deſcription has been here, and they have directed me where to find her.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: (apart.) Oh, pray where is—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'm here, Sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Had we expected this honour—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mr. Conner, (Bows. Mrs. Allbut frowns, and walks away aſhamed.)

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Oh, you're Mr.—the brewer, that— (with contemptuous indifference, then to Charles with ceremony and reſpect) Mr. Willows, I preſume. (All look at Charles with aſtoniſhment.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Moſt obedient, Sir Henry. I underſtand ſome property of mine is conſign'd to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: It is, Sir. I left town, on a viſit to my Lord Oakwood's here in this neighbourhood, and underſtanding from Captain Vanſluiſen, that you had juſt arriv'd, took the opportunity of paying my reſpects with hopes of the pleaſure of introducing you to his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir Henry, you're very obliging—I've ſome affairs to adjuſt, and then I'm at your ſervice. I ſhall dreſs and—

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Sir, the perils you've been in ſufficiently apologize—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sorry, Sir Henry, for what may have been the cauſe of your preſent appearance.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Thank'ee, Sir, I've had a ſevere loſs indeed— but come, Mr. Willows—I attend you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My father—ſiſter—Sir Henry—

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Sir, (bows to Willows.) Madam, your moſt devoted. (Very reſpectful to Maria.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (without.) No; you ungrateful cur. I diſcharge you—I've got a new ſervant.— Enter Grigſby. I'll ſee it Doctors are to be robb'd of their fees, and flung out of Brewer's houſes like empty oyſter-ſhells—you may ſkip— (to Charles.) Bring up my horſe from the Jolly Mariners.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Get along. (To Grigſby.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I will—and you ſhall get along to the Poultry Compter. Enter Shopman with a baſket of phials. You ſhall do nothing for me, (ſnatches the baſket from him, and places it on Charles's head) Here's my ſervant now—go you the rounds with them.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (takes the baſket and flings it off.) Come here affronting noblemen, you blundering fool!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: My med'cine ſpilt! ſo you take phyſic off people's ſhoulders, you moſt obnoxious paroxyſm, I'll ſend you ſuch a bill you ſhall have ſymptons of a bilious complaint— (turns, ſees Sir Henry) Noblemen— (bows)—mourning—good family for a doctor, (bows.)—Sir, it's my way to invite people of condition to my houſe—hope you'll honour my oxycrate—the moraliſts conſider'd health preferable to ſickneſs—and, my lord, nothing like exerciſe— reſt is the nurſe of diſeaſe—you ſee as a doctor, I ſpeak againſt myſelf—and for exerciſe, no ailment ſo mucilaginous as ſheeps-head-broth; ſome prefer butter-milk; and it is indeed as a lacteal lachrymoligon—

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Poh! turn! (ſpeaking off.)

div.stage: Excunt Charles and Sir Henry in converſation

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Allbut, our butler's compliments to you, deſires you'll ſend in a caſk of ſmall beer for the ſervants.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Sir! poh! turn! here you, my old chronic ſervant, take to your quadruped, and ungroundfel my ſimples in a limback ſcalager of immenſe featherfew.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Father!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why, Maria!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Mrs. Allbut!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (confuſed and embarraſſed.) Mr. Willows, I— cou'd—have—wiſh'd—Sir, that you had told us—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The firſt I knew of it myſelf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I ſuſpect he has brought home the pelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Mr. Allbut, I die with ſhame, for the ſcandalous treatment you have given him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: 'Pon my word, he's improv'd—when dreſs'd, I dare ſay he's a fine young man. Mr. Willows, you're very happy—Miſs, I give you joy. (Curtſeys.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (joyful to Willows.) Sir, I've brought home wealth, and I ſhall think my perils and labours in the acquiſition nobly repaid, if it can contribute to the eaſe and comfort of my dear, my honour'd parent!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My child!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: My good Charles! oh, now I may be enabled to raiſe the widow from her couch of ſorrow!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (with great reſpect and gentleneſs.) Well, I preſaged, when but a boy, and the ſweet child us'd to make ſuch a graceful bow; taking bread and currant-jelly out of my hand, I ſaid Charles was born to ride in his coach.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes, my love, and you remember, that day you gave him the ſmart box o'th' ear, (Mrs. Allbut walks up angry.) Mrs. Allbut, I call you to witneſs, when he was a little maſter, I ſaid, ſays I, "if that beautiful young gentleman was thrown into the ſea, he'd riſe again, with a bag-wig and a ſword by his ſide."

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Sir, we have now a very genteel neighbourhood—form little ſocial parties—happy if you'll make one, at a concert—or take a hand at Caſſino, or Rouge et Noir—Mr. Willows, if you'll honour our houſe—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir, are you keeper of the workhouſe?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Me!—we hope you'll dine—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
To take the run of the kitchen—father, ſhall I trouble you to order every inn in the village, open to all
comers?—ah! my good Sir and Madam, thank heav'n, I can now chuſe my company, and I'd ſooner ſteep my cruſt in the brook, than ſit at a table that hadn't a dinner for the poor man that wants one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall die with vexation!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Did my dear and I know, Charley'd bring home the rhino,
We'd have ſqueak'd, Oh, be joyful, and ſcrap'd violino.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I. Before Allbut's Houſe. Muſic and Shouting without.

sp.p: AY, there's the rich man's welcome, the full-mouth'd gratitude of beef and beer; what, and the Allbuts too going to partake of Mr. Willows' bounty! then Old Nick choke you in the ſhape of a pound cake.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Allbut richly dreſs'd from the Houſe.
div.p: Madam Allbut! Going up to Mrs. Willows's huzza at the Bear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Huzza!—but we ſhould pity the misfortune of tradeſpeople that want the advantages of early cultivation.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ay; we brewers and millers can't be expected to know much!

div.stage: Enter Maſter Jack from the Houſe awkwardly dreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Mamma, a'n't I too finely dreſs'd to viſit out ſervant maid?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ay, Maſter Jack, you're finer than ever your grandfather was.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Mamma, Jollyboy won't let me talk about Molly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: You muſt now ſay Miſs Maria, ſhe'll have an immenſe fortune.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Then, Mamma; I muſtn't ſay, hey the Molly, hand me the toaſt and butter?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Let my coach wait at my iron-gate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: This my indulgence, to let you dine out!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: So, then, after your ſhabby conduct you've been ſwilling Mr. Willows's wine—the devil's in your aſſurance!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: And now he can't behave himſelf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Why? don't you go up to the Roſe and halloo for Mr. Willows?—"You've no veneration for rich people."

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Not I. If a man has riches, ſo much the better for himſelf. I thank heav'n and my own induſtry—want none on't: nor if I did wou'd he give it—ſo what's any mah's riches to me?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You won't even make one at our pariſh feaſts and veſtry-dinners, you churl!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd you have feaſts and dinners?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To ſettle bus'neſs. Wou'd you have us meet in a field?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Meet in a horſe-pond, with your chins juſt above water, rather than feaſt upon the poor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: My coach, John!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ay; you've ſcrapes, bows, and bareheads; but it's only to your coach—give me the cordial ſmile of ſolid eſteem in my chay-cart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Draw up! I muſt pay my reſpects to Miſs Maria:

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Reſpects!—the poor girl you turn'd into the ſtreet!

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Mamma, Jollyboy's always prating, won't let me talk. (Whiſtles.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Here, Maſter Jack, by the way, you read me Orlando Furioſo. (Gives him a book.) The Maria ſhall peruſe my poem over our tea. (Aſide.) As a rehearſal I'll condeſcend—poetry may civilize this perſon—a brute! that cou'd ſtrike my child. (To Jollyboy.) Have you ever read ſympathy, ſenſibility, and humanity?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No; but I wiſh you'd get 'em by heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Man, do you viſit the muſe? (emphatical.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, when was you in Cockſpur-ſtreet? (imitating.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Have you tranſcrib'd my poem as I bid you?— Genius is above writing a mechanic fine hand.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Yes; but genius might know how to ſpell; and you write ſuch a damn'd ſcrawl, my love.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Ay, juſt like on an India tea-cheſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, here I've copied it out in a neat hand. (Gives the paper to Mrs. Allbut.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Gentlemen have no opinion of female literature; indeed we have not diſtinguiſh'd ourſelves in blank verſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: She'll be delighted with my improvements on it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: A Jeu d'eſprit of mine— (to Jollyboy) you may read it out. (Gives paper.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: (reads.) "Tall torrents tumble from the tow'ring cliff,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: "With a two-penny tiff.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: "The wild winds whiſtle with the roaring wave,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: "Dr. Grigſby for a penny did ſhave."

div.stage: Jollyboy throws down paper and exit.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Oh, my father! (laughs.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (bawling after Jollyboy.) Mind the "tiff" and the "ſhave" are mine—I'll give up any thing but my fame: I ſaw you was poz'd for a rhyme, my dear; not one in the whole poem, my chick!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Rhyme!—Do you know what blank verſe is, you wretch you!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Well didn't I fill up the blanks? Sweet!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Dare to interpolate! Oh! I muſt get a tranſcriber—ſome half-boarder at a top ſchool—a reduced clergyman's daughter—no! that young perſon Margery recommended.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, Widow Bellevue ſneaking to her hovel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Let's avoid this noiſe and feſtivity—joys are not for me! the Allbuts—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: One ſhou'd endeavour to do ſomething for this poor woman, as Miſs Maria was partial to her—How d'ye do, Mrs.—cou'dn't you make it out more comfortable, by a trial of—ſelling, ſome—trifling wares in—throw your cottage—into a little—ſort of—ſhop-window—a few children's toys, penny books, or—might keep a little ſchool. You've capacity to teach the infant ruſtics to ſpell, I ſhou'd imagine—Mr. Allbut, you'll advance the widow a few pounds for a ſet up?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I have it—there's one of my alehouſes, the Fox and Gridiron—people run away, (ſings) It's a pretty little reputable public houſe.—I'll put you into that: and for ſtock, I'll ſend you in a pin of beer or two.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p:
Hear me! You who have poſſeſs'd yourſelves of my right by rapine, and keep it by fraud—there is an eye that marks ye, a hand that holds a ſword—the hour will come to ſtrike! wealth that ſhou'd give exalted luſtre, renders you eminently deſpicable! Wretches, intoxicated!
that drinks the widows and the orphans tears! Oh! let the oppreſſor of the poor, reſtleſs on his bed of down, look within—there feeds the worm of conſcience—whilſt the patient object of his cruelty enjoys ſweet ſlumber on his bed of ſtraw—patience, oh, heavens! where is mine? (weeps) but I will be proud! (recovering herſelf looks with dignity and contempt on Mrs. Allbut, and exeunt with Edward. Mrs. Allbut confuſed, bridles and exit—Allbut puts his hands in his coat pockets, holds down his head and exit—Maſter Jack pulls down his ruffles and ſtruts off.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Ay, Captain, ſince the ſharks have miſs'd us, and we've got a firm footing on old England.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: I don't know what ſort of breakfaſt I'd be for a fiſh; but at this moment I cou'd eat a piece of a ſhark without oyſter ſauce, and yet I hav'n't the price of a red herring.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Here I promiſe you every comfort that affluence and hoſpitality can beſtow; that's my mother's houſe, (pointing to Allbut's.) She'll give us roaſt beef, a bumper of ſtout Madeira, and humming ſtrong beer of her own brewing, Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Faith; I wiſh we were ſitting down to it.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Now they're all gone out, if Miſs Maria cou'd ſee me—I'm afraid to— (Gives an caſy rap at the door.)

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: (knocks loud.) Peter, chuck Mamma's ſnuff-box out at window. (Door opens.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now, Captain, I'll introduce you to my mother.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: (ſtopping him.) What d'ye want?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The lady of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: But ſhe doesn't allow poor folks to come about door.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Then ſhe's much alter'd for the worſe—Can't I go in?

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: Sha'n't!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (to Jack.) Pray, my boy, didn't you learn with the cook and eat with the chaplain?

sp.speaker: Maſt. J.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Nothing: only you're better fed than taught.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But I'd ſpeak with Mrs. Bellevue.

div.stage: Exit Jack into the houſe and ſlaps the door.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: That's now Mr. Allbut's—Mrs. Bellevue, Sir, is my mamma.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: (aſide.) This my brother.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: She lives in the cottage here.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: (aſide.) And is it ſo?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (aſide.) Upon my honour I'm afraid the roaſt beef is all eat up—the Madeira is all ſupp'd up, and the ſtrong beer turn'd four—William, the firſt interview with your mother won't admit of a ſtranger—I'll wait for you in the cabaret yonder—don't be aſham'd—as an enemy, when you retook my prize you cut me down with your hanger—as a friend after we were ſav'd in the waves, and ſince partners in adverſity, you've been kind and gentle, and millions of gold cannot increaſe my reſpect where I admire courage, and honour humanity.—

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: That's joy for a great rich gentleman that's come.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Joy!

div.stage: Enter Charles and Sir Henry Check (laughing.)

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: For your good cheer now you're the greateſt creature, ha, ha, ha! Your pretending pennyleſs, an excellent trial!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—And the damn'd Allbuts too—their fulſome compliments—But you had ſomething to ſay, Sir Henry?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: A thought has ſtruck me—your ſiſter is very amiable—under any engagement?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why, there was a young gentleman, a very dear friend of mine; but I fear he's dead—for—

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: I've loft my only ſon—our family, title, and my fortune, muſt now go to a nephew, for ſome time not upon terms with his mother—I may have been wrong —if we cou'd bring about a match between your ſiſter and this my nephew.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: With my ſiſter's conſent, you have mine, Sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Beſt not introduce my ſiſter Bellevue till ſhe can make ſome appearance, (aſide.)—Full of buſineſs, Mr. Willows—Oh, did you ſee an Iriſh French officer about here, ſince—But you'll conſider—adieu! excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Abrupt enough! A marriage of faſhion and
bus'neſs propos'd by the baronet and banker. Now to comfort poor Mrs. Bellevue—but this is the charming ſtranger's forbidden cottage and meadow. Is my viſit here love or charity?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I'll walk in the air till ſhe wakes.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: By heavens, William Bellevue! (ſurpriſed.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Find my mother reduc'd! and I return'd to her with one ſhilling!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My poor fellow! (aſide). William!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: (ſurpriſed). My dear Charles! I heard you follow'd me out to ſea.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Juſt return'd to England.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sorry to ſee you too come home with a ſhatter'd hulk.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Not yet heard of my good fortune (aſide.) I think no occaſion, but I'll try him too (aſide). Aye, William, and no hope from my father or ſiſter! all gone badly ſince with them too.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My beloved Maria and my friend! (Turns aſide.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, does your honour wiſh—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Damn the fellow, (ſhoves him off.) Eh, William —well? Strange we never met abroad. Though your mother did ſend you off from my ſiſter, I think ſhe'll be ſoften'd to ſee me come home thus. Come, we'll ſtep into her houſe, and over a bottle and a cruſt we'll talk of our voyages. Oh, Bill, you've a ſnug, warm birth to come home to—but poor me—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Charles, that's my mother's habitation now.— (Charles affects ſurprize and concern.) A gentleman waits for me at the Grapes—ſtep acroſs—I'll ſee my mother, and come to you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But, ſhou'd any thing prevent you, I've no— (touching his pocket.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Here, Charles, (gives him money.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Perhaps I deprive you.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Oh, no, I'm ſtill a few ſhillings ſtrong—good bye.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
(joyful). Give my ſiſter with a hundred thouſand pounds to baronets and bankers!—My generous poor friend have her. But. hearing nothing from him ſo long, may ſhe not ſince have choſen another—ſo fine a girl muſt have had
many dying ſwains— (looking out). Doctor Grigſby! Your agreeable apothecaries know all that's done, ſaid, or thought in every family—I'll aſk him.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Their open alehouſes! I muſt watch for my friend in the ſtreet: in the ſtate of my pocket I'm afraid to venture into a tavern yet, though I'm juſt hungry enough. If I dine with a gentleman, it ſhall be at his own private table—Oh, they tell me this is the great man that pays the piper—An airy kind of a morning dreſs—May be he'd invite me. Sir, your moſt obedient— (Bows.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir, (bows) you have the advantage of me.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No, 'faith, Sir, it's you that have the advantage of me—You know where to find a dinner, and I muſt firſt find the philoſopher's ſtone (aſide.) You've charming air here—ſo ſharp and keen, gives one ſuch a nice appetite.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir, it's wholeſome air.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; but it's not toothſome.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No, he won't (aſide). Sir, (bows) ſince my mouth muſt be idle, I'll try if my noſe can't get a little employment (aſide.) Sir, a pinch of your ſnuff, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sir, I don't take any.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, theſe are bad times indeed, when a ſea officer can neither get ſnuff or mutton. (Half aſide.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: A gentleman by his air and manner, but ſeems an oddity.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: My patients cannot ſpare me to go to London—beſides this rich man will be now for cramming himſelf with turbots and turtles eggs.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: May be he'd invite me. Sir, I am your's alſo. (To Grigſby.) (Grigſby ſtares.) Nor you neither.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Poh!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Then poh! for you. Conſtable, you'll catch my thief!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But who is he?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p:
If he knocks out your teeth, I'll give you a fine tooth I bought of a blackamoor. (Sees Charles.) The nabob—how lucky his believing I didn't know him this morning—his ſiſter loves me— (aſide.) (Cringes) Sir, if
you dance in the evening, that is, a minuet, now loſe a little blood—my lances ſo ſharp and obtuſe—my ſweet little parlour—ſattin hair—bottom'd chair—handl'd China coffee cups—Sir, your arm ſhall be ty'd with your own philaſtic garter—ſtretch'd out, hold one of my fluted ſilver candleſticks, and to divert your thoughts by a pleaſing object before you in a glaſs-caſe, my ſkeleton of Levi Barrabbas—none of your ſixpenny London bleedings, pewter porringer, yard of liſt and a broom-ſtick—by the heavens, Sir, I'll charge you two guineas—there will be bleeding! (Pompous.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But now for information—Doctor, as well as the body, you're often conſulted on the ſtate of the mind?—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: The Munro? Ha!—Theraptica, (looks cunning.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why, Doctor, you ſeem to have acquir'd aſtoniſhing ſkill in your anatomy, pharmacy—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Dear Sir, only ſymptoms in pharmacy, I have a pretty meadow, ſome corn—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Blockhead! (aſide.) Pray have you heard—do you think my ſiſter has form'd any particular attachment!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: In the Pleura ſhe was in danger, but I diſpers'd it—young women ſubject to theſe periodical diagonals.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I mean love attachments, ſince—ſpeak out—the man that can make her happy ſhall have her.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Shall he? When only Allbut's maid, I never minded Miſs Maria's leers at me, and how ſhe took my part when Jollyboy, (aſide.)—Sir, your ſiſter has long form'd a moſt laſting attachment.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Long! (aſide.) Oh, William—but a doctor I don't mean—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: There is a certain worthleſs, cephilalgical poor dog—the very thought of him is her elexir cardialgia.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then ſhe has kept her heart for— (aſide.)—His povrty is nothing to any body.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir, you've a cauſtic for that!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I think him worthy of the fineſt woman in England!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, (bows.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I'm certain he's endow'd with ev'ry gen'rous quality—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, (bows.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And doctor, the poor cephalalgical dog, as you call him, ſhall have her, in preference, even to the nephew of a baronet.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Shall I?—then ſhake hands my gen'rous brother!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What, yourſelf! You? (agitated.)—(aſide.) Impoſſible! this can exiſt only in his own folly.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes, here he is; but what brings me here?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What, your change—hav'n't ſo much i'th 'till—ſend you a bag of camomile. (Apart.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So, Sir, for all my caution, you wou'd come hov'ring about the cottage, and my walk in the meadow! (Archly.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Oh! you moſt charming!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Hold! I never liſten to heroics.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: As you ſay, Ma'am, they are very ridiculous, (confus'd, (looking out.) My ſiſter—to think of this fellow, but ſhe can't—yet the ſex fall into ſuch unaccountable inconſiſtencies.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Mrs. Bellevue is a very charming widow, ſo don't you follow me in there.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: As you ſay, Ma'am, excuſe me a moment, there's a lady coming that—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I don't wiſh to interrupt you and the lady—I deſerve this, for my forward indiſcretion.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh, brother, have you ſeen Mrs. Bellevue?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: If ever ſo depraved, ſhe'll be aſhamed to own it to me—I muſt draw concluſions from her manner— (aſide.)—Maria—

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Mr. Charles Willows—fling your money about among drunken mobs!—I wiſh with all your joy, you'd let your golden ſun ſhine upon the houſe of ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Thank'ee, my honeſt monitor.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Apprehend the honeſt monſter! I'll ſwear he robb'd me—here will be fractures—as I'm going to be married, muſt take care of myſelf for the good of poſterity. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Wasn't it Mr. Jollyboy—he rob!—did you (to Jollyboy.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: An honeſt man's word againſt the oath of a—good by'e, (ſhakes hands and exit.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Here muſt be probity (gives Jollyboy a paper.)—My almoner—go! you "find out the houſe of ſorrow," and diſpenſe joy.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: A hundred pounds! "I ſhall get ſaucy again." Huzza! I give you leave to roar and be happy, tho' you are a rich man, or you ſhall laugh by proxy—I'll be your repreſentative in joy, as well as charity; and a bleſſing on you as you give it—Tol, lol, lol.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Brother, you're very wrong to entruſt—you're deceiv'd—he's not the man you think him; I aſſure you, he us'd the poor doctor moſt horridly—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (aſide.) Her poor doctor! Oh, her partiality is evident,—for him, ſlander ſuch genuine integrity!—love a wretch that cou'd deny me! who, when he ſuppos'd me in indigence—take him—let him be a huſband; but I am no more a brother.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: What can he mean? (looking out.) Heavens! ſure that's William—he return'd too!—Then 'twas my dear William that Charles meant—perhaps they met abroad— why at firſt conceal it? Could my love be unkind to him? oh, no, my William, the delight I receiv'd from even a thought that I might ſee you again, and now is it thus my wiſh is accompliſh'd; my father loves us, he'll remonſtrate with Charles; better his gold had ſtay'd in the mine than make him violate the deareſt ties of duty, love, and friendſhip.

div.head: SCENE II. A Cottage, a Table with Books, Work, and Newſpapers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Maria has ſent me the news-papers, ſweet girl! ſhe takes every occaſion to amuſe and oblige me, (looks out). Eh! what ſtranger, Edward?

What, you brought the poor man in, to relieve him? that was right, my love—your brother William is a ſailor, if he lives—and for his ſake, tho' we have only a little, you know it's always my wiſh to ſpare—when diſtreſs takes the ſhape of a forlorn ſeaman.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: But, Madam, he—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: When in danger, England looks to a ſailor for protection—but that no longer wanted, gratitude ſhou'd forbid us to neglect the diſintereſted improvident; too gen'rous to layiſh only on himſelf, the fruits of preſent ſucceſs, and too thoughtleſs to provide againſt future misfortune.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Mamma, he has ſome great bus'neſs with you, yet, when I told him you was aſleep, he gently look'd over you—oh, but I never ſaw ſuch a look! tears fell down his cheeks—and then, for fear of diſturbing you, he ſtole ſo ſoftly out again—Sir! (calling.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: (looking out.) Perhaps brings news of—
'Tis himſelf—my William!—my dear beloved ſon, (he kneels, ſhe throws her arms round him.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Mother, can you forgive—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No, the mother ſhou'd aſk pardon of her child—I baniſh'd you, my life's comfort, from my arms— from your country—I wrong'd, and heaven has aveng'd you—Ah! William, look, I've no home for you, and it's now you ſeem moſt to want a home.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Edward has told me. Cou'd Allbut be ſuch a villain! didn't my uncle interpoſe with his advice? his fortune?—is he in London, I'll—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No, William, I muſt now forget I had a brother! Since your departure he has had an heir to his eſtate—a Baronet's title too! No! Sir Henry now never ſees me!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But why?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: My fault is adverſity, and that the proſperous cannot forgive.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Then, Madam, I muſt not face my uncle—With hopes to raiſe a fortune for Maria, I quitted the Captain with whom you ſent me—rambled to the Eaſt Indies—but
our relation wou'd not encourage my diſobedience—I left him in diſguſt—and after many perils, was returning in a Dutch India Ship—we were taken by a Frenchman, but in the night, I got upon deck and—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: (ſnatching up a news-paper.) Your ſhip was re-taken: then the brave youth was not drown'd!—Was it you, my William, that preſerv'd—it was! I ſaid I knew none ſo likely to perform ſuch an action as my ſon, my gallant William—oh, my child! in this thread-bare jacket ten thouſand times more welcome to your fond Mother, than if clad in jewels acquir'd by the plunder of the unfortunate!—my ſon! my ſon! (embraces him; looking out.) Oh, the lady that Maria told me of.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: And my appearance—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Madam, pardon my intruſion—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Madam, you do me honour; Maria has informed me, that you wiſh'd to come—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I do, Madam; the miller and his wife are good people, but coarſe—the man blunt—yet, as Maria tells me, not too honeſt—an aſylum with you will make me happy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Madam, it ſhall be my endeavour—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You ſhou'd know ſomething of me tho'—a family diſagreement drove my father, a man of rank, from his country—I follow'd him to France—he was a Captain in their navy.—I hav'n't heard of him ſome years, which gives me much doubt and uneaſineſs—I retir'd, Madam, to this village, 'till I either hear of him or am recall'd by my friends.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Here you may have tranquillity; but cheerfulneſs you muſt bring with you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Yes: but 'twas taken from me by the way, by a moſt unkind young man—juſt come from over ſeas—I believe only to vex me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Over ſeas? What ſort of man?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, very handſome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: A ſtranger—muſt be my William!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Aye: I thought he look'd like a falſe William.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: My ſon!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Indeed, your ſon! but do you think he has given away his heart?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: He loves, and is belov'd, (looking out) and here comes the very amiable girl.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (looking.) Aye: the very, very ſame that—What cou'd ſhe mean by her fineſſe to me at the mill this morning—as a meer ſtranger—expreſs ſuch feeling for his ſervice to her father! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, where's William?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And ſhe left him this very moment (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Not far off—Maria, you're very fine, what is this?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Hav'n't you heard? Ah, Madam, I fear an union with William is now far diſtant.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (joyful.) Is it?—I aſk your pardon, Ma'am, I'm very rude, but I—I— (confus'd.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (to Maria.) Now, my beloved, (ſees Louiſa.) here again?—want your change—hav'n't ſo much in the till— ſend you ſeven bottles of peppermint— (aſide.) I'll celebrate our brother's ſucceſs by illuminating my windows—the village ſhan't blaze in bonfires, and my houſe dark—wiſh I'd a few ſquibs, or ſome little guns to make revolutions.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: (to Louiſa.) Miſs, a ſervant in mourning aſks for you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Madam, your pardon,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: That ſeaman was your brother, my love; go to him.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What, William!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: But, Maria, you aſtoniſh me—what can have turn'd your heart againſt my William?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Talk not of Williams or Georges—her heart muſt turn to nobody but Jack Grigſby—her noble brother! to give her to me, in preference to the nephew of a baronet!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: To you? impoſſible that Charles can be ſo abſurd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Nephew of a baronet—muſt mean my boy— Is Charles this rich man, whoſe arrival has occaſion'd ſuch univerſal joy?—Oh, then his contempt for my William is accounted for—here's the world! ſtep this way, my ſon— never mind your dreſs.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Madam, my brother's gone. He over-heard you all talking, and went out greatly troubled.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Which way, Edward?

div.stage: Exeunt Mrs. Bellevue, Maria, and Edward.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Her brother giving her to me—very handſome— but I muſt dreſs terrible ſmartiſh—with the ecclat of her fortune, I ſhall indeed be a phyſician—Doctor! Beautiful!— I will buy a deplomar—job-coach—pretend to be reading— own footman thump muffled knocker—door open'd by lady of the houſe—ſtep ſlowly up ſtairs—ſhoes creak—chair plac'd—patient's bedſide—all ſilent, reading my looks—pinch of ſnuff—ſtop-watch—ſqueeze pulſe—touch guinea—beautiful! thrice beautiful! ha! hum!

div.head: SCENE III. A Road. Enter William, agitated.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Maria falſe! My mother in indigence—this my home! Where ſhall I turn my face?—Heavens!

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: You'll ſup at our houſe, Sir?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (ſeeing William.) I don't like your ſtraggling ſtrangers—it's Willy Bellevue!—He come back too ſhabby! Yes: he wants to play on us the ſame game that Charles did—certainly rich—ſeems poor, only to try us.

sp.speaker: Waiter.
sp.p: (apart to Allbut.) Aye, Sir; gad, you've hit it! like Mr. Willows, he certainly has brought home the ſhiners—and I'll tell 'em ſo up at our houſe— (Aſide. Runs off.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He'll play the devil with me for ranſacking his Mamma!—Oh, this, 'twas that puff'd her up when ſhe trim'd us ſo this morning!—I'll ſeem to think him poor—then the greater merit in my kindneſs. Willy Bellevue! (joyful.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: (aſide.) The wealthy brute that oppreſs'd my mother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: So glad to ſee you come home again!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: If I had even gone away in your debt, I have brought no money to pay you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Sly! (aſide.)—Talk of money between friends—I ſaid when you went abroad, you were too honeſt, like Charley Willows, to make fortunes, by cutting Rajahs throats— and running off with their coats.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Has Charles brought home money?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He has, my Honey. My ſweet Boy, he has been as great a rogue to get pelf—as yourſelf, or myſelf (aſide.) He has been ranſacking abroad—brought home rupees enough fill a porter-butt.—No, give me the honeſt conſcientious man, tho' he hasn't a halfpenny to buy his dog a roll—and Billy, I reſpect you by my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Charles make fortunes! This doesn't correſpond with his ſtory to me—perhaps, flaſhing away to procure a little civility, or to marry off his ſiſter—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: That dog of a waiter has been blowing this all about, (aſide.)—Don't mix with that rabble at the Roſe— come to my houſe, Billy tho' you hav'n't a ſouſe.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: But my Mother.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: You are my Brother.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I. An elegant Drawing Room in Allbut's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Allbut.
sp.p: QUICK, Peter! Put wax in the girandoles and luſtres— blazing cluſters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I hope you hav'n't aſk'd Mr. Willows and his party here?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No; but there's another young old friend of ours arriv'd in England (running about and adjuſting furniture) Jenny!—bid cook buſtle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: What do you mean by your buſtles and illuminations?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I tell you here's a gentleman—there he is—give me a kiſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: With ſweet conſent to conjugal endearments thus the turtle-dove—but oh, fie! (going to him ſmiling.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lord! I don't want to kiſs you—I only ſaid it for the rhyme's ſake. (run off.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Perhaps here's indeed ſome perſon of condition, and my dreſs— (goes to the glaſs.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (without.) This way, dear Sir,—Mrs. Allbut waits the honour of receiving you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Why didn't you give me more notice?

sp.speaker: Allb.
sp.p: Pray walk in, Sir, (ſtands ceremoniouſly expecting.)
Mr. Bellevue, Mrs. Allbut.— (introducing.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (ſtarts.) Ah!—introduce your filthy tarpaulins to me—who's there! Shew the fellow out.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Madam, though its quite a novelty my being deſired to quit this houſe—yet as it was once my mother's, I think I can find my way. (going.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Stop! (Holds him. Apart to Mrs. A.) The devil's in you—are you going to make the ſame blunder with him you did with Charley Willows? You won't be convinc'd that he's come home with the caſh till you ſee the banker's chariot.—Billy, be ſeated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Upon my ſopha! (pulls it away.) Go about your bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Stay, Peter!—A bottle of ſack for me and my friend.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Now is it the wife or the huſband that gives me the real welcome? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here's friendſhip without intereſt, and a ſpeedy kick up to all ſcoundrels. (Drinks and coughs.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: One wou'd think, Sir, that you got the wine out o' th' rivers—I inſiſt—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (apart.) So rich—brought home from the Indies— my dear Billy (ſhakes hands) cargoes of nankeens, bamboos, pepper, tea, china, fontaragree, lacca, and bagatapaex.— Love, doesn't Billy look charmingly? The dolts without there think him quite a man of gold—and I humour'd them in it, tho' I know 'twas no ſuch thing— (apart) he has money enough to ruin us for chouſing his mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (changing manner.) Proteſt I did not know him at firſt!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: There, you ſee ſhe did not know you at firſt— (apart) ſeem to think him poor and behave kind to him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: And the Willows' family—this croud of ſucceſs ſo provoking! (aſide.) My dear William, I'm ſorry for your own ſake you've had no better fortune abroad; but you are as welcome—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: As the poſtman!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: When I reflect on certain proceedings towards my mother, I am at a loſs how to account for this very extraordinary kindneſs to myſelf.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Billy—didn't I tell you the good lady cou'dn't ſtoop to live in this ſcene of bus'neſs?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Mrs. Bellevue, my dear, you know, was a woman of quality—deſpis'd every mechanic idea, and we indulg'd—let her have her own way.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I've plagu'd myſelf with the whole property merely to rid the dear gentlewoman of trouble of bus'neſs—I've toil'd, while ſhe lives ſnug in the cottage without a care to make a grey hair. Peter, has John taken the coach for Mrs. Bellevue?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (aſide.) My coach!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir, I'll call and bring—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I ſuffer the dear lady to ſhuffle through the mud!— What ſhou'd a gentleman keep a coach for, but to accommodate people that are genteel and honeſt—Go! (to Peter.)

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Our coach for the poor widow—well!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: (Aſide.) Some balance this againſt Charles's unkind—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Billy, conceal your poverty and you'll get enough to help you; for your ſordid raſcals are always thruſting their money on thoſe they are ſure don't want it—your travels may have exhauſted your caſh—command my purſe. (Gives money to William.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Nay, my love; you musn't engroſs all Mr. Belevue's compliments—my dear William accept—I'll not be refus'd— (giving him her purſe.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Eh! the world ſeems better than I thought it—yet this unexpected (aſide)—Pray, Sir, how long has the marriage been talk'd of between Maria and your Doctor here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: The firſt I heard of it. (Apart.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Or I, (apart) huſh!—Only from their finding out your empty pockets.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I'll get the doctor's bones broke—offer to take ten pounds from me? Grigſby's a terrible rival! abus'd you at ſuch a rate only for thinking of his Maria—my love, you know he ſaid he'd kick Billy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Scoundrel! but is he worth my anger? I'll conſult my Iriſh friend the Captain. (aſide) (A loud knock without.) My figure!—if you expect company permit me—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Poh! What's a man's outſide? We'll pack 'em off, and then us three will make party quarri over a ſnug bit of ſupper. Ecod, my love, Billy ſhall have ſhare of Doctor Grigſby's little wild pig—hey, diddle dig!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: (looking out.) Mrs. Bellevue in my houſe! this is indeed a ſacrifice to one's intereſt!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Ma'am, Mrs. Bellevue wou'dn't come in the coach.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Proud wretch! ay • ſhe'll not join in William's deception upon us—our ſudden notice of her will appear ſo unaccountable, I ſcarce know what colour to give it. (Retires.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Theſe people muſt have ſome motive for their reverſe of conduct—has Providence wrought it in their hearts, or do they dread my ſon's indignation: and yet who is faultleſs! If their contrition is real, I ſhou'd meet it with forgiveneſs—I hope you'll excuſe my warmth this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p:
Oh, Madam, pay don't mention it, as the poet ſays,
The heart that's wounded by the dart of fate,
Aſſumes in dire diſtreſs ſublimer ſtate. It hurts me, Madam, to think—that—ſtill ſome little miſunderſtanding or other ſhou'd have unluckily kept us at ſuch a diſtance. I fear—I have been wrong—the ſight again of your dear William reviv'd ſparks of former kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Accept my thanks for the reception you have given him—he left me juſt now in great trouble of mind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Madam, won't you pleaſe to ſit—Peter! Chocolate.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Chocolate too!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Now, Madam, you ſhou'd be happy—how aſtoniſhingly Mr. William's improv'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: He's certainly very good, and I am ſure he has gratitude—he's hurt exceedingly at ſome change in his friend Charles, but your attention to him in his preſent circumſtances—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Circumſtances! Gratitude! Can ſhe too give into this little artifice her ſon is playing off upon us? I'll try her farther. (Aſide.) Life is ſubject to viciſſitude, and did we withdraw our countenance from our friends in the hour of calamity we ſhould be barbarians, Mrs. Bellevue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: But, Madam; tho' my ſon is now diſtreſs'd, and has found me in extreme indigence—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Diſtreſs'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: The hour may yet come when—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Stop, Madam; (riſes) anſwer me—Is your ſon's poverty real? It muſt be ſo—this creature is above a falſhood.
sp.stage: Enter Peter, offers Chocolate to Mrs. Bellevue—Mrs. Allbut put its aſide.
sp.p: What's the blockhead about? Mr. Allbut! (calling.)
That fellow isn't worth a ſhilling!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What my ſweet Willy! No?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I'm ſure he cou'dn't attempt to impoſe the contrary upon you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: He did! Becauſe he ſaid he was poor, I thought he was rich—it's ſuch a damn'd lying world! Give him a ſupper!—Betty! Take the pig from the fire!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: He took my purſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: So then, all this humanity that I—

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: I like people chatt'ring of humanity, that have nothing to loſe by it!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Fine talk of hoſpitality, when they can't lay in coals enough to boil an egg for their ſallad! Peter! (bawls) Where's the ſailor?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Sir, he went out, he ſaid, to look for ſome Iriſh Captain.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bring an Iriſh Captain upon us!

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: We're robb'd!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And bobb'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: What can they mean? What new miſchief to my unhappy child?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Pray, my pretty lad, was there e'er a young William come in here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I fancy you mean my ſon, Sir,

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Your ſon! Oh, then may be, Madam, you're his mother?—a moſt noble preſence! I vow to my honour I ſhou'd like to ſit down by her ſide to a piece of roaſt beef. (aſide.) Stop! (to Peter who is removing) ſuppoſe I partake of theſe people's kindneſs, and ſave them the trouble of an invitation—Madam, will you do me the honour to take a diſh of chocolate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Sir, have you ſeen my ſon?—What do theſe people intend?—I am tortur'd with the moſt extreme and perplexing ſolicitude!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p:
Poor lady! Then I'll divert her ſorrows with an account of my own misfortunes (aſide.) Firſt, Madam, it may be neceſſary to inform you I'm an Iriſhman and a foreign officer; but when I did accept a French commiſſion, England had no ſhare in the quarrel; for, Madam, let me be blown into chops and griſkins from the mouth of a cannon, when I
turn my face as an enemy againſt George my belov'd King, and Ireland my honour'd country!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir; your acquaintance with my ſon?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, we ſought ourſelves into the ſtricteſt amity —Madam, I took a Dutch prize and he took it from me—ſo when my kicking and cuſſing about cou'dn't ſave it, I jump'd overboard—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: How, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: And to ſecure myſelf a welcome in 't'other world, I brought the brave boy, your ſon, along with me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! then it is—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: We were pick'd up together, and got to ſhore— our little money was ſoon ſpent—loyalty forbids my return to France.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: To what perils have I expos'd my boy!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: My brother, Ma'am, is a Lord; no fault of his, he was born to it—not, Madam, a humpy Lord; but a real right honourable, that can row a boat and play cricket—that walks about the town in an old coat with a ſtar tack'd to it, that the people might take off their hats and ſay—oh, he's a duke!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: But, Sir;— (with anxiety.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Madam, I don't know how it was; but we cou'dn't agree, and you know that muſt have been his fault, becauſe I happen'd to marry one day—my wife had only beauty and virtue, and I ſpent my own little fortune in all the ſplendor of a younger brother; then I came away in a huff.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Sir; will you be a friend to my ſon?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Ay, Madam; and I hope I can be a friend to him: for our family eſtate and title deſcend only in the mate line; to be ſure my elder brother's wife, the Lady CaſtleSomers was juſt brought to bed; but I left Ireland in ſuch a hurry, that I don't know this moment, whether I am an aunt or an uncle.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: I'll have him!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Sir, will you take a diſh of chocolate? (drinks.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What! (ſtaring.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Madam, do you prefer ſome dry toaſt, or plumcake?

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: We're not at all ambitious of this honour—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: The intruſion wasn't my choice.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Nor mine; but ſince they're here make free.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: You make very free!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: To ſup our tea.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, you're come here to drink tea; never mind being aſham'd about it—you're heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. A.
sp.p: Can the man know that we're in our own houſe?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (ſurpriz'd ſets down his cup.) Oh, you're Mrs. Allbut—then there's ſix-pence for your cup of chocolate, and keep the halfpenny yourſelf, (throws down money.)

sp.speaker: Allb.
sp.p: Here's an affront! (pockets the money.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Sir, can I ſpeak with you?—you can give me information that my ſon's modeſty will not ſuffer him to diſcover.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (bowing, takes her hand.) Mr. Allbut, Sir, have the honour to— (Allbut bows) deſpiſe you.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Oh, Ma'am, I fear I've done miſchief—I lent a caſe of piſtols out of the hall to Mr. Bellevue and—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: William taken piſtols—ah, true—gone after Doctor Grigſby—then I know where to find my purſe—Peter—my juſtice wig—musn't loſe my money! I'm a magiſtrate, and authority begins at home.

div.head: SCENE II. Before Grigſby's Houſe. Candles at a Window.

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Sir, do you think we've candles enough up?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: No. I wiſh we had colour'd lamps—a fine tranſparent C. W. Mr. Willows would take that for ſuch a high compliment—They've made a bonfire at the Roſe and Crackers—ſince I've no pateraroes, I'll give another double ſhot. (takes piſtols.)

sp.speaker: Shop.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you'll alarm the whole village!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p:
(Bawling) Tom! touch 'em with turpentine, and they'll be ready to light up as ſoon as dark. Have I the ſquibs?—yes. Dam'me how I'll fling 'em about!—Landlord
of the Roſe won't take his wine from me, tho' I made him a preſent of two decanters, ſixteen to the dozen—a nice occaſion to break his windows—the glazier's my cuſtomer! Now I'll go up to drink tea with my bride, and lay my vardi againſt Jollyboy—a few links to my paliſadoes—noble blaze! (goes in.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Let Sir Henry Check, whoever he is, wait! Buſineſs muſt give way to honour. William ſays that his rival is one of the learned profeſſions; but whether in the law or the army I quite forget. However, my friend can't be degraded by fighting him. I muſt deliver my meſſage in a decent manner—
But which is—oh, Mr. Jack Pudding!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What! Oh, I remember you.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Which is Grigſby's?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Sir, what do you want with Mr. Grigſby!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Faith I'm come to call him out.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Well, he's out already.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, you mean he's not at home. Now here I'm making a blowing-horn of this buſineſs, and we ſhall have the ſheriffs and beadles all about us— (aſide.) I don't come about any quarrel.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Who cares whether you do or no—What the devil do you want with me?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: You! Oh, this is a comical looking learned profeſſor. (aſide.) Then you are the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Gentleman—he, he, he!—civil enough—but his brogue, moſt infernal hellebore. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Firſt, Sir, I'm an officer.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Cuſtom-houſe! (aſide)—come to ſearch? dam'me, Sir, down into my cellar—I have a few gallons of nullage among my pieces of wine, ſo flouriſh your gauging-rule— who cares for your exciſe ſcratching-irons, and meaſuringgallopers.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Softly, ſoftly, with your ſcratching and galloping. I'm come from a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: (aſide.) Oh, an order! Sir, beſides my old bottl'd, I've neat wine in the wood.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Wood! yes, you ſeem to have a ſup in your head—be quiet—I am come from—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh, a patient!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: My friend is—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Dropſical.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No! my friend is—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Feveretical.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No! he's—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Gout or rheumatical.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt; he's—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Eriſypelatical.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No! I tell you he's—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Sanguine apoplectical.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (impatient.) No, no! Sir! no! he's exceedingly hurt—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Hurt! oh, a fracture in the os caries.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No, Sir! but—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A luxation of the os humerum.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: No ſuch thing, Sir! it's—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A diſlocation of the membrum funerum.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir! no, it's—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A gibbous body in the latera.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: 'Sblood, Sir, no, no! I tell you no!—Why my friend's coming here to ſhoot magpies. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Then, zounds, Sir, tell me what is his complaint, for it is impoſſible I can gueſs.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Sir, he does not complain about it; but you might have known that he has an affection—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Oh, a convulſive affection in the midriff—theſe ariſe from ill humours in the—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: He's good-humour'd enough, Sir,—yet he cannot digeſt—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A bad digeſtion—I underſtand—alexipharmic— then, Sir, after ſpeaking aloud, ſinging, running, or drinking, as we of the faculty ſay, dilutifactitious liquification of ſwallow's-neſt—he ſhou'd take four ſcruples, two drams—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: He is a gentleman, and deſpiſes drinking drams— Sir, I don't know what you mean?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, water-gruel, if his ſtomach's ill.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: He has a very good ſtomach; ſo have I— water-gruel! By the ſmoke of all your chimnies, your pots and ſpits go merrily, but a man may walk about and look at the outſide of your houſes—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Sir, don't talk of water-gruel.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Why true, Sir, as we of the faculty ſay, ſome prefer butter-milk—but—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, here's a national reflection! Hark'ee, friend, talk again of potatoes and butter-milk, and—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Why, Sir, ſheep's-head broth is more mucilaginous, as a lacteal lachrymoligon, with an emmolient mixture of Jews-ears and pulveriſh'd cockle-ſhells—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Stop!—don't ſay another word, but tell me what you mean!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: What do I mean—Album grecum—a decoction of logwood—there's expectoration for you!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Will you give my friend the meeting?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: And will you give him ſatisfaction?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I flatter myſelf I am able to do that—I don't fear giving ſatisfaction to him and his whole family—I'll cure him—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Here comes my friend!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Abroad! here's variety!—a patient coming out without the help of an undertaker!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: This affair, end as it may, muſt alarm my mother, (aſide.) Well, Captain, have you told him?—But wou'dn't a caning— (apart.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Fie, fie, to be ſure he's a foul-mouth'd man; but he's ready to anſwer what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I'm aſham'd to tell my friend this fellow's ſo deſpicable; yet, then he'd not think of urging a ſerious contention.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Why it's Willy Bellevue!—his pia mater!— (looking at his forehead.) How d'ye do? (ſhakes hands.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: That's right! Courage without malice— We'll all ſtep yonder, and in five minutes time perform the operation.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Operation!—my inſtruments—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Seems a very good caſe in your hand.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Theſe! ha, ha, ha! That will be one way of curing indeed!—very good—after a leaden pill, the patient cou'd never complain o' th' doctor!

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Trifling with this fool!—I'll ſee Maria and upbraid her—No! I'll inſiſt upon an explanation from Charles—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Stop, William! Come this way, and among the trees we'll—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: The trees! Step into my little parlour.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Little parlour! Oh, you don't want to ſettle the affair 'croſs a table.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I'll tie him in a chair.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Then with my ſaw—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Saw!—Death and 'oons, if you're ſo deſperate, have you got a ſecond?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: He's gone out for candles! Bring my razor— hem—my amputating knife!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Do you think we're in America going upon aſcalping party! (draws a knife) —and by the Heavens I'll— (in a low tone.)

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Bring my ſalve-box, diachylon, and tourniquet.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: None o' your tourniquets or tomahawks.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I'll handle you as gently—The lint and bandage— I'll give you ſuch a dreſſing—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Handle me! I'll give you a dreſſing!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Help! Murder!

div.stage: Enter Allbut, (in Juſtice-wig) with a Conſtable and Jollyboy.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here, Conſtable, knock him down and take him up!
He has broke the peace! Why didn't you beat him?— Juſtice! Where's William?

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, I'll have you! (looking out.) I've heard of your juſtice! (collars Allbut.) Liſten, oppreſſor of the widow —plunderer of the orphan—you call for juſtice! As I now ſhake your ugly body before this bleſſed ſun that's going down upon your head, let your villainous ſoul tremble at night upon your pillow, you ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Bravo, Captain! Oh, how I ſhould like to croſs the rough ocean of life in conſort with ſuch a man of war— we'd chace affliction, take diſtreſs'd merit under our convoy, and bring it ſafe to the harbour of comfort.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: What d'ye talk of, Captain—I'd keep up a fire with e'er an admiral in the navy.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
Yes, in a ſnug parlour with a poker in your hand. Mrs. Allbut has promis'd, inſtead of wiping away her tears
at fictitious woe, when real miſery appears, ſhe'll put her hand in her pocket—and now a word with you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: At church I'll ſit in my pew.

div.head: SCENE III. The Village. Enter Charles, dreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I will not be acceſſary to Maria's certain diſgrace and future unhappineſs, by tacitly complying with her caprice; her union with this ſorry fellow muſt not be.

div.stage: Enter Sir Henry and Louiſa, dreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You're very good, Sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Sir—Miſs Louiſa Somners. Madam—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Henry, I could have introduc'd this gentleman to you. We have met before—hav'n't we, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: To my infinite pleaſure, Madam. (Bows.)

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Oh, this is very well—then, ſince you're already acquainted, I hope a ſimilarity of ſentiments will ſave me even a wiſh for a more tender intercourſe between two ſuch amiable perſons. (Going.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Now, Sir Henry, pray don't go.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Madam, didn't I promiſe to find a very unexpected friend for you?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: True—to oblige me, won't you excuſe Sir Henry? (To Charles.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Self-intereſt, Madam, when the cauſe leaves me with a lady I ſo much admire.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Follow that, Mr. Willows— niece to an ſriſh peer—a deſirable alliance! When your ſiſter Maria gives her hand to my nephew, our family will be very leading in both kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: This Mr. Bellevue's experiment to prove his friend was well enough; but his conduct to his mother and this young lady is very equivocal—leaves one in a cottage, and breaks a ſolemn engagement to the other. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Moſt obedient.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh'd for an occaſion to talk to you a little, and you ſhall not again ſend me out of the way. (mimicks.) "Ma'am, I beg your pardon, I muſt ſpeak to this lady"— and the poor ſavour'd—this lady, ſoon follows me in a ſhower of piteous tears—don't be offended; but I muſt inquire— What reaſon had you to break off that match?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then ſhe has heard of my ſiſter Maria and — (aſide.) Madam, 'twas diſproportionate—a very vulgar connection.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (aſide.) True; I heard ſhe was ſervant to Mrs. Allbut, but I thought her a very elegant woman tho'.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Madam, ſhe reflected a diſgrace upon me; I'd wiſh to have conceal'd it from you; but ſince it's notorious, her partiality for the barber ſurgeon here—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, then you're jealous of Dr. Grigſby.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Jealous, Madam!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Now I've done that pretty well, I'll queſtion him on his treatment to his poor mother. (aſide.) Sir, you've acquir'd a fortune abroad—don't you bluſh not to take a little more notice of your honour'd parent?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Madam, I have taken every notice that obedience and duty can dictate—my honoured parent ſhall never want an eaſy chair and a cheerful bottle.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, this is a horrid man!—he'd inſinuate—Sir, no aſperſion can injure Mrs. Bellevue in my opinion; and I'm ſorry that your conduct has turn'd it ſo very much againſt her ſon—but a child's protection the parent ſhall never miſs whilſt. I can prove myſelf the friend and comforter of aged benevolerce.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Very odd this! What can ſhe mean—what conduct of mine cou'd change her opinion of William Bellevue?— Why angry that my old father ſhou'd have an eaſy chair and a bottle—but the ſweet character of her charity prepar'd my heart for the impreſſion made by her beauty. As Sir Henry obſerves—if I cou'd obtain her with all my wealth, a reſpectable introduction into life is an object—but my ſiſter and this Grigſby! no! ſhe ſhall have Sir Henry's nephew— a ſplendid thing! her affections are alienated from William, ſo I don't injure him.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Why 'tis he—ſo dreſs'd! the report's then true of my dear Charles—I give you joy, though your motive for concealing your ſucceſs from me—but anſwer me; do you know of your ſiſter's change?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Ay, William! let her go—ſhe's not worthy of ſuch an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Then ſhe has your approbation of her perfidy?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: (aſide.) Call me to an account! this is rather building too much upon our former intimacy. I ſhou'd deſpiſe myſelf if pride of riches, or hope of more honourable alliance, cou'd warp my heart from an old friend—yet—look'ye, Sir—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Your marrying my ſiſter is now out of ſight; but to atone for her perfidy, as you indeed juſtly call it, and in conſideration of our former acquaintance—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Acquaintance! (much hurt.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Whatever pecuniary embarraſſments you may labour under, if the ſum you'll find here is not ſufficient to extricate you, you may command— (gives a ſmall pocket book.)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Sir, I thank you—for—your—bounty—my heart will burſt— (aſide) your humane—feelings—for—my abject poverty— (with great emotion flings down the pocket book.)
Enter Mrs. Bellevue, agitated. Madam, I have loſt my Maria!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Then Char les retaliates upon you my former endeavours to ſeparate you from his ſiſter—unkind at ſuch a time! but what I've juſt heard is a treaſure of triumph!— Sir, was not the veſſel that brought your wealth to Europe captur'd at ſea?—And but for the intrepidity of one brave young man, might you not, at this moment, be as much the wretched object of ſcorn, as you now ſuppoſe my ſon?—Behold the preſerver of your fortune!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Was William the ſeamen that— (aſtoniſhed.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: He was. My gallant ſon! who forgot he had a life to loſe, when call'd by honour, and impell'd by duty—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: The owner of Captain Vanſluiſen's cargo! (ſurpriz'd.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My friend! The companion of my youth!—I've pierc'd the heart that loves me—I ſee, now, pride did bias me when I—my generous benefactor too!—that gave me his laſt ſhilling! (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Now, Sir, where's your ſiſter?—Give me leave to introduce my nephew—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I know nothing about your nephew, Sir Henry.
Here, ſiſter, take your William; and if ever I hear a word of your infernal Doctor Grigſby; I'll cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen, your moſt obedient—brother, your's—how d'ye, Widow? Your moſt humble Gally Pot— I'm juſt coming from the moſt pleaſing adventure—a certain officer was misfortunate enough to fall into my hands—he! he! he! affronted me! but dem'me I ſick'n'd him of ſuch aquatic frolics—my little cane here emancipated the pulveriz'd ligaments of his cinabar lobſter-ſhell—I ſwitch'd him— I knock'd—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: (without.) I'll catch you, you raſcal; where is the dog?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Some gentleman loſt his dog—hey, Pompey—Pompey— (whiſtles and runs about.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: I'll beat you as black—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: A black dog—a pretty dog. (Whiſtles.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh, you're there.

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Where Pompey—poor fellow. (Whiſtles.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: I'll razor and tomahawk you; you raſcal, I aſk'd for a ſecond, and he ſaid he was gone to buy candles!

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: I take ſhelter in your arms—oh! my love!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Depart! or by the powers!—

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Depart? Oh, by the powers of med'cine, I'll make ſome of you depart!—loſt my wife!—I'll—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: You'll what?

sp.speaker: Grig.
sp.p: Squibs and aquae fortis! (Enter Louiſa.) Want our change—hav'n't ſo much in the till—ſend you a pound of bees wax—a fine crocodile. (Runs off.)

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Dear William!—brother!—why ſuppoſe I cou'd think of ſuch a wretch?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then our errors all proceeded from his abſurd vanity.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Here, Madam, is the friend I promis'd— (pointing to the Captain.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Eh! (looking.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Heav'ns! Do my eyes deceive me, or—it is—

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Louiſa!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p:
Ladies and gentlemen, won't you wiſh me joy? Why this is my cherub! my darling! that follow'd me to
France and back again—flying after me through all my wars like a dove with an olive-branch in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Dear father, by letters, thro' the medium of Sir Henry, my uncle acknowledges his unkindneſs; and intreats you to return in the moſt cordial terms of affection.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: This morning I walk'd about here, and did n't know where to break my faſt.—If he gives me a bit of an eſtate, I'll build ſuch a country houſe! the ſign, my family arms, and my motto—walk in and eat, all that want a dinner! Ah, child! there's only one thing more you cou'd do, to make me happier—here's the neat boy, that cut and ſlaſh'd your dear Father about—that ſtood upon the deck, ſhaking the bullets out of his hair like a mermaid.—With your leave, Madam; (to Mrs. Bellevue.) Louiſa, take from my hand William Bellevue.

div.stage: (Louiſa looks ſurpriz'd at the Captain and Charles.)

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay, William, this will be puniſhment, if you reject my ſiſter, and rob me of happineſs for ever.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I ſee it! Oh, what a ridiculous miſtake have I been under!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you ſuppos'd that my name was Bellevue. (To Louiſa.)

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Sir, might I aſpire to render myſelf acceptable to your charming daughter?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: My honour'd mother! My dear Charles!—Here, firſt ſet his lordſhip an example. (To Maria.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: (without) Come along!—don't be aſham'd of ſome good, by way of variety!—

div.stage: Enter Jollyboy and Allbut, in Apron and Sleeves, with a Box.
div.p: Give them! Madam, there are all your papers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Who are you? (to Allbut.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Your clerk.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: What! the great juſtice o' peace!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, honeſt little Jack Allbut.

sp.speaker: Capt. M.
sp.p: Oh! little honeſt Jack Allbut.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: He reſtores your houſe, and all your's—his ill-got poſſeſſions.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, I'm a man of conſcience, I deſpiſe wronging the widow and the orphan, becauſe I don't like to go to law— with a long claw.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So, my worthy landlord, when people owe you money, you make them pay you in your own coin—but Margery taught me to thank you for your ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: And me to retract my ill opinion of a good man.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My dear William, by a look back to our paſt adventures, you'll enjoy the recollection that you have borne unmerited adverſity—and I, whilſt my pride in undeſerved proſperity is puniſhed, ſhall be taught by my reception here, that when diſtreſs preſents itſelf before me, the bittereſt drop in the cup of human miſery is, the world's contempt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Thus you'll deſerve your wealth—and when inſpir'd by Heav'n to diſpenſe the bleſſings it has ſent you alone for that benign purpoſe, wait not for the application of modeſt indlgence—ſeek her in her ſad retreat, cheer her with your ſmiles, wipe away her tears, comfort and relieve her.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Charles, begin your acts of benevolence by ſhewing your gratitude to this worthy man, (pointing to Joll.)

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Thank you, Madam. But as the wind ſometimes diverts itſelf by playing in the ſails of my mill, and people will obſtinately perſiſt in this odd whim of eating bread, I think I may do pretty well as I am. Ay, we may ſee the world in our village! But a fig for the world—Let induſtry ſecure independence; and if wealth or poverty will come, let the rich man be proud only of his power to be the poor man's friend.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.byline: Written and ſpoken by Mrs. ESTEN.

sp.l: THE World in a Village!—Lord help the ſilly man!
Where could he ſtumble on ſuch an old faſhion'd plan!
Here's a fine Lady for me, exhauſting her ſtore
In diſcharging of debts and relieving the poor;
And, inſtead among Bucks of making a racket,
Falls in love with a ſwain, oh, faugh! in a jacket.
The Lover too, rich, young, without one toniſh vice—
No racing, no betting, no intriguing, no dice.
The World in a Village!—I declare I'd as ſoon
Expect natural traits from a World in the Moon.
Well, if they give me ſuch parts, I'll ſo it manage,
Commence an Authoreſs myſelf, and write for the Stage.
The World in a Village! 'tis the World in a Town—
That's your ſort, that's the go, and, 'faith, I'll write 'em down.
Give to the Poor!
'Tis what Ladies in high life can't afford to do,
They have Dreſs, Equipage, Balls, Concerts, Pharo, Loo,
Debts, Duns, and Fees for every ſecret Billet-doux.
Lady Fanny Dawdle, juſt riſen from her down bed,
In the hard talk of nicely blending white and red,
Glancing her languid eyes from the dear glaſs a minute,
Cries, "Betty, unfold that paper,—ſee what's in it".
"Yes, my Lady:
"It's a petition, Mem, from a poor ſoldier's wife,
"Laying in of twins, Mem, juſt as he loſt his life!"—
"Bleſs me, Betty, this freckle ſpoils every feature;
"I'm vaſtly ſorry I can't ſerve the poor creature:
"I've too much feeling for an income ſo ſmall—
"Don't forget Lady Froth's ticket for my grand Ball."
Then the men, oh, they are precious niddy noddies,
With their throats tied up, falſe calves, and taper bodies:
Pert men at ſeventeen, inſolvents at twenty;
At twenty-five, invalids—old men at thirty.
Here's daſhing Dick Squanders the great Nabob's rich heir,
With caſh at his banker's, and ten thouſand a year,
Would he his aſſociates of faſhion diſgrace
By rememb'ring a friend with a ſorrowful face?
No, demme, not he, he's up to all that there gig—
Know a poor friend!—Oh, curſe it, that's a pretty rig.
But one likeneſs, I own, is ſucceſsfully taken,
A likeneſs ſo ſtrong, it cannot be miſtaken;
In the true Britiſh ſailor how often we meet
Generoſity's home—Liberality's ſeat!
Who, tho' hardy, humane; if improvident, juſt;
Ever conſtant in love, ever true to his truſt;
Who invites the unhappy to ſhare in his meſs,
Who ne'er turn'd his back on a friend in diſtreſs;
Who, 'midſt danger and death, will courageouſly ſing,
May our arms be victorious, and long live the King!
